virtual_issues.vi_title: 2023 Fenn: Native and Structural Mass Spectrometry
virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Special Issue was created in honor of Professor Dame Carol Robinson, recipient of the 2023 ASMS John B. Fenn Award for a Distinguished Contribution in Mass Spectrometry. Prof. Robinson is recognized for her contributions to the development of mass spectrometry methods for the analysis and characterization of membrane proteins. This Special Issue includes publications from authors invited by Prof. Robinson to contribute and exemplifies her impacts on native and structural mass spectrometry.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: professor carol robinson
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Special Issue honors Prof. Dame Carol Robinson as the recipient of the 2023 ASMS Fenn Award.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Green hydrogen, produced through water electrolysis powered by renewable energy, is an essential component of future global energy systems. In this Thematic Issue of <cite>Chemical Reviews</cite>, we present a collection of reviews on some of the key research topics related to the design of components and understanding of the elementary processes in current and emerging water-electrolysis technologies.

Chemistry makes the invisible visible through the use of imaging agents that can monitor the elements and molecules of life at a variety of length scales with both spatial and temporal resolution. In this context, fluorescence and luminescence provide visual readouts that can be widely adopted by specialists and nonspecialists alike, from laboratory researchers to medical clinicians and field technicians to children playing with glowsticks and fireflies during the long nights of summer. This Thematic Issue delves into the latest research achievements in this storied and highly active field in the design and development of chemical reagents to decipher new fundamental biology and to translate this knowledge to advanced diagnostic and/or therapeutic platforms.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Recent Advances in Aqueous Rechargeable Energy Storage Materials Research
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Aqueous rechargeable batteries, capacitors and other forms of energy storage devices are rapidly emerging as a viable alternative to traditional Li-ion based energy storage technology in recent years. Aqueous rechargeable energy storage devices can offer notable advantages in safety, environmental sustainability, cost-effectiveness and fast charging capabilities compared to Li-ion counterparts. This collection presents the latest advancements and research trends in the development of materials and design strategies for aqueous rechargeable energy storage applications, as published in <cite>ACS Applied Energy Materials</cite>.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Recent Advances in Aqueous Rechargeable Energy Storage Materials Research Cover Image
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This collection presents the latest advancements in the development of materials and design strategies for aqueous rechargeable energy storage applications

virtual_issues.vi_title: 2024 Pioneers in Energy Research: Robert Brown
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Special Issue dedicated to Professor Robert Brown, included in the 2024 Pioneers in Energy Research. Read the editorial and the Q&A with Robert Brown.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: professor robert brown
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This special issue is dedicated to Prof. Robert Brown, our 2024 Pioneer in Energy Research in the field of biomass, bioenergy, and biorefinery.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Highlights of the North American Chemical Residue Workshop
virtual_issues.long_blurb: The North American Chemical Residue Workshop (NACRW), previously known as the Florida Pesticide Residue Workshop (FPRW), is an annual meeting for researchers interested in analysis of pesticides, veterinary drug residues, and other chemicals at trace levels in food, animal feed, and the environment. Beyond its focus on North America, the meeting is becoming increasing global with speakers and attendees from other continents. As a workshop, the meeting provides training to develop and improve technical knowledge in analysis methods and techniques, and incorporates networking to promote collaboration. This virtual special issue contains outstanding contributions from researchers at the NACRW since the 50th edition in 2013.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Corn plants growing with their roots visible in soil
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This virtual special issue contains outstanding contributions from researchers at the North American Chemical Residue Workshop.

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
This collection of papers from three ACS journals (Inorganic Chemistry, Journal of the American Chemical Society, and Organometallic Chemistry) honors recently retired Distinguished Professor Philip Power of the University of California Davis. The papers curated for the collection illustrate the sustained progress and broad impact of Prof. Power's research. An accompanying editorial by the guest editors introduces the collection.

Guest Editors:
Cary R. Stennett, UC Irvine
Joshua D. Queen, UC Irvine
Karin Ruhlandt, Syracuse University
Yang Peng, Soochow University
Clifton L. Wagner, Louisiana State University
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: photo of Philip Power
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Collection highlights the broad and impactful work of Professor Philip Power of the University of California Davis.

virtual_issues.vi_title: 2024 Pioneers in Energy Research: Haoshen Zhou
virtual_issues.long_blurb: This special issue is dedicated to Prof. Haoshen Zhou, our 2024 Pioneer in Energy Research in the field of batteries and energy storage for his outstanding contribution to the area of high energy density secondary battery materials and systems. Read the editorial and Q&A with Haoshen Zhou.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: professor haoshen zhou
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This special issue is dedicated to Prof. Haoshen Zhou, our 2024 Pioneer in Energy Research in the field of batteries and energy storage for his outstanding contribution to the area of high energy density secondary battery materials and systems.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Polymers for the Clean Energy Transition
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Polymers underlie many of the technologies enabling the transition to clean and renewable energy, from energy storage devices such as organic solar cells and solid-state batteries, to lightweight composite materials used in the energy production industry. The transition to clean energy is also being assisted by polymer recycling and upcycling technologies as well as concerted efforts to reduce our reliance on single-use plastics. This Virtual Special Issue from JACS Au features some recent innovative work in this area which highlights the impact polymer research is having on efforts to realize this transition.
This Virtual Special Issue is led by an introductory Editorial (DOI: 10.1021/jacsau.4c01152) written by Associate Editor Prof. Rodney Priestley and guest editors Profs. Emily Davidson and He Tian.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Hands holding green plastic pellets on a blue/green background
virtual_issues.short_blurb: A Virtual Special Issue from JACS Au showcasing some recently published innovations in polymer science which are helping to facilitate the transition to clean energy.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Gustavo E. Scuseria Festschrift: New Developments in Electronic Struture Theory
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Gustavo Scuseria’s career of over 45 years continues to impact the study of electronic structure theory. His seminal work on density functional theory and coupled cluster theory has been applied to large molecules, carbon nanostructures, and strongly correlated systems. Dr. Scuseria has also built a community of computational chemistry and materials science researchers by organizing conferences, initiating collaborations, and serving as the long-tine co-editor-in-chief of a JPC sister journal, <cite>the Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation</cite>. He has an outsized influence on the over 150 students, postdocs, and visiting scientists he has directly mentored, many of whom have contributed to this Festschrift in his honor.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: carbon atoms bonded together into a nanostructured object
virtual_issues.short_blurb: Gustavo E. Scuseria has had a lasting impact on the field of electronic structure theory. This Festschrift features new research by many of his colleagues and collaborators.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This virtual special issue of ACS Engineering Au has been curated to bring focus on new and impactful insights, innovations and (process) intensification (or combinations of these) for effectively addressing current and future challenges in broad areas covering applied chemistry and chemical engineering. An editorial written by the Editors introduces the VSI.
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This virtual special issue highlights research addressing current and future challenges in broad areas covering applied chemistry and chemical engineering.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Organic Synthesis and Catalysis Enable Facile Access to Bioactive Compounds and Drugs
virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Collection showcases the latest advances in organic synthesis and catalysis, highlighting innovative strategies for the efficient and selective construction of pharmaceutically relevant compounds, natural products, and drugs. Emphasizing groundbreaking work in total synthesis, biocatalysis, and catalytic methodologies—including transition metal-, photo-, and organocatalyzed reactions—this Collection reflects the cutting-edge research recently published in ACS Central Science.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: organic synthesis
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Collection showcases the latest advances in organic synthesis and catalysis, highlighting innovative strategies for the efficient and selective construction of pharmaceutically relevant compounds, natural products, and drugs. Emphasizing groundbreaking work in total synthesis, biocatalysis, and catalytic methodologies—including transition metal-, photo-, and organocatalyzed reactions—this Collection reflects the cutting-edge research recently published in ACS Central Science.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Chemical transformations have long been a focus of physical chemistry—whether initiated by heat, light, or charged particles like electrons. Ultrafast spectroscopy enables fundamental insight into the mechanisms of chemical transformations by probing processes such as bond breaking and formation, energy transfer, proton transfer, and electron transfer which occur on ultrafast time scales.  This virtual special issue showcases papers published in <cite>ACS Physical Chemistry Au</cite> covering different aspects of ultrafast studies of dynamics of interest in physical chemistry. As ultrafast studies in physical chemistry continue to advance and reveal new insight to further our understanding of fundamental physical chemistry, this special issue provides a glimpse of recent activities in this area.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: a beam of energy exciting molecules in a solvent
virtual_issues.short_blurb: Studies of chemical transformations at ultrafast time scales provide fundamental insight into chemical processes, and continues to expand as a subfield in physical chemistry.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: As environmental pollution presents new challenges, sustainable materials are needed to meet those challenges through sensing and remediation. Magnetic-based nanohybrids have gained interest due to their unique structural, smart functional, and tailored physicochemical characteristics and their potential to measure and remediate trace contaminants, which may be challenging using existing alternatives. This Virtual Special Issue from ACS Omega will showcase studies about magnetic nanohybrids' design, synthesis, characterization, and environmental applications.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A person doing environmental analysis, to highlight a collection of papers on magnetic nanohybrids for environmental applications.
virtual_issues.short_blurb: his Virtual Special Issue showcases studies on the design, synthesis, characterization, and environmental applications of magnetic nanohybrids.

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
The Journal of Medicinal Chemistry continues this series with a collection put forth to showcase Drug Discovery in Italy. In this collection, you can view a selection of original research articles, perspectives, editorials, and drug annotations from the region published between 2020 and 2024. The selected publications represent the vibrant and flourishing medicinal chemistry research being conducted throughout Italy. We hope this collection encourages the next generation of medicinal chemists to submit their original findings, drug annotations, and perspectives to the Journal of Medicinal Chemistry.

Antonella Ciancetta, Early Career Board, Journal of Medicinal Chemistry; University of Ferrara, Italy
Maria Laura Bolognesi, Associate Editor, Journal of Medicinal Chemistry; University of Bologna, Italy
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Map of Italy highlighting drug discovery in this region
virtual_issues.short_blurb: The <cite>Journal of Medicinal Chemistry</cite> is pleased to introduce a collection on Drug Discovery in Italy, highlighting medicinal chemistry research from this region.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Recent Advances in Simulation Software and Force Fields
virtual_issues.long_blurb: The evolution of theoretical chemistry has been profoundly shaped by the development of sophisticated computational tools, which have revolutionized the way scientists tackle molecular systems. Structural biology and biophysics have particularly benefited from the emergence of equally apposite computer programs to address complex questions hitherto impossible to answer. While software provides the computational framework for molecular simulations, the accuracy and reliability of these simulations hinge on the quality of the force fields employed. This Virtual Special Issue seeks to highlight the latest innovations in both software and force field development, underscoring their critical role in pushing the boundaries of computational science.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Recent Advances in Simulation Software and Force Fields
virtual_issues.short_blurb: The ever-evolving landscape of computational chemistry owes much of its progress to continuous advancements in software tools and the development of accurate force fields.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Natural products (NPs) have historically served as the basis for a variety of therapeutic applications including treatments in the fields of oncology, infectious diseases, and central nervous system (CNS) disorders. In this cross-journal thematic Virtual Special Issue, we feature contributions from the Journal of Medicinal Chemistry, ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters, ACS Bio & Med Chem Au, the Journal of Natural Products, ACS Chemical Neuroscience, and ACS Chemical Biology. You will find a wide range of topics covered including the isolation of compounds, medicinal chemistry lead optimization, and virtual screening of natural product libraries. We hope our readers will enjoy this collection of manuscripts aimed to provide a better understanding of how natural product scaffolds can be used in drug discovery.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: natural products driven medicinal chemistry
virtual_issues.short_blurb: In this Virtual Special Issue, we highlight drug discovery efforts based on natural products or their derivatives.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Special Issue covers methods and applications of computational mass spectrometry and highlights the exciting theme presented at the 38th ASMS Asilomar Conference on Computational Mass Spectrometry. Articles includes in this Special Issue bring together a diverse range of innovative investigations that explore cutting-edge methodologies in computational MS and its applications across proteomics, metabolomics, glycomics, and polymer analysis. The Computational Mass Spectrometry Special Issue was managed by JASMS Associate Editor Lingjun Li and Guest Editors Aivett Bilbao and Devin Schweppe.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: computational mass spectrometry
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Special Issue covers methods and applications of computational mass spectrometry and highlights the exciting theme presented at the ASMS 38th Asilomar Conference on Computational Mass Spectrometry.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Celebrating 50 Years of Surface Enhanced Spectroscopy
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Fifty years after a couple scientists decided to “roughen” their silver electrode to increase the available surface area for adsorption, researchers are still benefiting from the surprising findings in the experiment. This special issue celebrates those observations, which marked the first published surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) experiments. The research included here involves novel optical and photocatalytic materials, new fundamental insights, and a large number of interdisciplinary applications ranging from food security to biomedical devices. Utilizing modern statistical methods and machine learning, SERS will continue to play a major role in analytical devices and applications, solidifying its role among the most important nanotechnology tools shaping our future. The Special Issue includes articles published in Analytical Chemistry, The Journal of Physical Chemistry C, or ACS Omega.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: surface enhanced spectroscopy data
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Special Issue is a joint effort between Analytical Chemistry, JPC C, and ACS Omega showing the many ways spectroscopic techniques have benefited from signal enhancement by surfaces.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: In 2004, a joint experimental-theoretical study of formaldehyde photodissociation showed that the CO + H<sub>2</sub> products could form while avoiding the conventional transition state barrier. Since then, this behavior, known as roaming, has been observed in several other systems, including both unimolecular dissociations and bimolecular collisions. This Collection showcases 35 papers in The Journal of Physical Chemistry that describe different reactions, through experiment and theory, that exhibit roaming. The impact of the formaldehyde observations twenty years ago will continue to grow and spread beyond these works, revealing new and unexpected insights into chemical behavior.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Images of molecules and spectra to visualize roaming reactions
virtual_issues.short_blurb: Roaming, a mechanism involving frustrated near-dissociation followed by intramolecular reaction, has been observed and actively studied over the past twenty years.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Pharmaceutical Sciences and Drug Delivery Research from Early Career Scientists
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
This virtual special issue (VSI) of Molecular Pharmaceutics highlights the broad range of high-quality work led by early career scientists (≤ 10 years from PhD) in pharmaceutical sciences and drug delivery publishing in the journal. Contributions from around the globe illustrate the innovative and collaborative nature of research in the field. An editorial written by the Guest Editors introduces the VSI.

Guest Editors
Lauren Austin, Merck & Co., Inc., USA
Orlagh Feeney, Monash University, Australia
Patrick O'Dwyer, University College Cork, Ireland
Weijun Wei, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, China
Chun-Wan Yen, Genentech Inc., USA
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This virtual special issue highlights the broad range of high-quality work led by early career scientists (≤ 10 years from PhD) in pharmaceutical sciences and drug delivery.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Biodiversity: A View from Science & Technology
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Biodiversity is crucial to the conservation and protection of the environment globally. It is fundamental to the ecosystems that support crop production and food security, and the health of humans, plants and animals. Better biodiversity leads to improved water and soil quality, greater crop yields and resilience, and can help combat climate change. The importance of biodiversity was recently highlighted as the theme of COP16: the 2024 United Nations Biodiversity Conference held in Cali, Colombia. This Collection highlights a series of outstanding articles published in ACS journals that can help to improve biodiversity.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Biodiversity: A View from Science and Technology
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Collection highlights a series of outstanding articles published in ACS journals that can help to improve biodiversity.

virtual_issues.vi_title: 2024 Pioneers in Energy Research: Juan Adánez
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Special Issue dedicated to Professor Juan Adánez, included in the 2024 Pioneers in Energy Research. Read the editorial and the Q&A with Juan Adánez.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: juan adanez
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This special issue is dedicated to Prof. Juan Adánez, our 2024 Pioneer in Energy Research in the field of environmental and CO2 issues.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Xueming Yang Festschrift: Advances in Laser Spectroscopy and Chemical Dynamics
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Xueming Yang is an innovative and pioneering experimental physical chemist who has made significant contributions to a wide range of technological advancements and scientific discoveries. He is a leading figure in the field of reaction dynamics, advancing our fundamental understanding of processes in the gas phase and at surfaces, and has made significant contributions that go well beyond his groundbreaking research. Not only has he promoted the development of free-electron lasers (FEL) in China, he has cultivated an ideal scientific environment for young scientists to tackle complex and fascinating problems in reaction dynamics. His colleagues and friends deeply appreciate his broad perspective, strong leadership, boundless enthusiasm, genuine collaboration, and valued friendship. In order to express their gratitude they have supplied numerous outstanding contributions to this Festschrift.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Interference pattern and blue chemical background representing laser spectroscopy and chemical dynamics
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This issue highlights 68 articles in laser spectroscopy, chemical dynamics, and other topics within the scope of the journal.

virtual_issues.vi_title: 13th Wartburg Symposium on Flavor Chemistry & Biology
virtual_issues.long_blurb: The 13th Wartburg Symposium on Flavor Chemistry & Biology was held from October 3 to 6, 2023, in Eisenach, Germany. The scientific program that consisted of seven keynote lectures, 26 talks, 13 flash poster presentations, and 72 posters focused on the current hot spots in flavor research, including “functional flavor genomics & biotechnology”, “flavor systems: molecular decoding, interactions and perception”, “chemosensory perception and signal processing”, and “next-generation technologies in molecule discovery and analytics”. This special issue highlights outstanding contributions from all of the scientific sections mentioned above and thus provides an overview of the progress in flavor research as presented and discussed during the 2023 edition of the Wartburg Symposium.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Liquid being poured from a beaker into a test tube, with an orange gradient overlay in the background
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This special issue provides an overview of the progress in flavor research as presented and discussed during the 2023 Wartburg Symposium.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) remains one of the greatest public health challenges we face. World AMR Awareness Week, which takes place November 18-24 every year, aims to bring awareness to this ongoing threat. In this Collection, you will find contributions from 20 ACS journals highlighting the latest achievements in research designed to combat multi-drug-resistant pathogens.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: world amr awareness week 2024
virtual_issues.short_blurb: In recognition of World Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR) Awareness Week, this Collection aims to raise awareness and provide a greater understanding to the fight against antimicrobial.

virtual_issues.vi_title: One Health and Vector-Borne Parasitic Diseases
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
The One Health concept in drug discovery encompasses the interdependent global effort put forth to link human, animal, and environmental health. This Virtual Special Issue features articles, letters, perspectives, and reviews from academic groups, not-for-profit organizations, and industry researchers in the theme of “One Health and Vector Borne Parasitic Diseases”. ACS Infectious Diseases hopes this special issue encourages our readers to explore this new vision of drug discovery within the context of the interconnected One Health approach.

Maria P. Costi, Guest Editor, Dipartimento di Scienze della Vita, Universita degli Studi di Modena e Reggio Emilia, Modena, Italy
Anabela Cordeiro-da-Silva, Guest Editor, Instituto de Biologia Molecular e Celular, Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal
Félix Calderon, Associate Editor, ACS Infectious Diseases, ViiV Healthcare US, Branford, United States
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: a variety of microbes
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Virtual Special Issue aims to highlight the collective efforts of the vector-borne parasitic disease research community.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: The theories and quantitative approaches of physical chemistry are being increasingly applied to understanding macromolecular interactions and dynamics inside cells. Understanding these complex systems will require a combination of experimental and computational approaches from physical chemists. This Virtual Special Issue focuses on experimental and methodological advances in cellular biophysics that further our quantitative understanding of the living world. These articles span important techniques from microscopy to spectroscopy, introduce the development of new fluorescent probes and new sample geometries, and delineate state-of-the-art data-processing algorithms. The impact of physical chemists on cellular biophysics will continue to grow as the range of accessible targets and amount of permissible complexity in these biophysical chemistry experiments increases.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Advances in Cellular Biophysics cover art
virtual_issues.short_blurb: Physical chemistry underpins several important advances in cellular biophysics, particularly in data processing and fluorescence microscopy and spectroscopy.

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
From controlled synthesis and characterization to understanding properties and designing applications, a whole-process precision chemistry approach is essential for realizing the full potential of diverse clusters. This virtual collection from Precision Chemistry, titled "Whole-Process Precision Chemistry for Clusters", features the latest research articles, reviews, and perspectives from leading scientists in this rapidly developing field. It highlights the whole-process practices of precision chemistry in material design and synthesis, characterization, establishing precise structure-to-property relationships, and practical applications, emphasizing how a holistic approach to precision chemistry can unlock the full potential of clusters .

This collection is accompanied by an invited Editorial written by Prof. Jianping Xie. We hope readers will enjoy exploring this collection.
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This collection features the latest research in this field, emphasizing how a holistic approach to precision chemistry can unlock the full potential of clusters.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Last month, the 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to David Baker “for computational protein design and Demis Hassabis and John Jumper “for protein structure prediction.” One of the fundamental tenets of chemistry is that structure predicts function; the concepts and tools created by these Nobel Laureates have greatly amplified our ability to translate from sequence to meaningful biology. We hope you enjoy this collection of articles, gathered from more than 30 ACS journals, which highlight the breadth of this field’s research.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: protein design and prediction
virtual_issues.short_blurb: We celebrate the 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry with research focused on new concepts, tools, and applications of protein design and structure prediction.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Advances in material science and engineering have been pivotal in developing many environmentally relevant research areas. Over the past few decades, numerous publications on advanced material-based environmental applications have been published in <cite>Environmental Science & Technology</cite> and <cite>Environmental Science & Technology Letters</cite>, including, but not limited to, capacitive electrochemical deionization, advanced oxidation processes (AOPs), (electro)chemical reduction, microbial fuel cells (MFCs), membrane separation, heterogeneous catalysis, electrochemical reactors, environmental sensors, oil/water separation, adsorption, among others. This Collection showcases the breadth of research topics covered by our journals in the field of materials science and environmental applicability.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: interconnected hexagonal shapes in shades of green and blue
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Collection showcases the breadth of research topics covered in <cite>ES&T</cite> and <cite>ES&T Letters</cite> in the field of materials science and environmental applicability

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Special Issue is a collaboration between the Journal of Proteome Research and the Canadian National Proteomics Network (CNPN) organized by JPR Associate Editor Jennifer Geddes-McAlister (University of Gelph) and Nicole Hansmeier (Luth Collage at the University of Regina) and highlights Canadian researchers (i.e., authors residing in Canada or those that have trained in Canada) and their important contributions to discovery and innovation within proteomics over the past year. We hope you appreciate the innovation, tools, and biological insights provided by these Canadian researchers and the diversity in approaches, expertise, and institutions of leaders within the proteomics field and how these discoveries are bridging knowledge gaps and improving current workflows.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: canadian proteomics
virtual_issues.short_blurb: A collaboration between the Journal of Proteome Research and CNPN, this Special Issue highlights Canadian researchers and their important contributions to discovery and innovation within proteomics.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Chemical separations play crucial roles in modern society, enabling access to food, energy, and medicine. Membrane-based separations, particularly polymer membranes, have become central components in desalination, wastewater treatment, and biomedical devices.Advancing our understanding of the physics of polymers is crucial to unlocking the full potential of polymer applications, and developing next-generation membranes.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Polymer Physics of Separation Membranes
virtual_issues.short_blurb: Focusing on the intricate physics of interfacial polymers. Understanding the physics of membrane polymers is crucial to unlocking next-generation applications.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Celebrating Authors of Energy & Fuels Most Impactful Articles (2021)
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Energy & Fuels is pleased to present this special issue that features a collection of papers contributed by researchers who previously (co-)authored at least one of our journal’s most impactful articles in 2021. Those most impactful articles ranked within the top 3% most-cited articles published in Energy & Fuels in that year.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: celebrating authors of energy & fuels most impactful articles
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This special issue features a collection of papers contributed by the authors who published the top 3% most cited articles in Energy & Fuels in 2021.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Precision chemistry represents an ultimate goal of chemical research, for example, controlling properties and reactions and obtaining precise and accurate chemical data. Artificial intelligence can play an important role in these two aspects of precision chemistry. This virtual collection from Precision Chemistry, titled "Artificial Intelligence-Driven Precision Chemistry", features the latest research and perspectives from the leading scientists in this rapidly developing field of precision and intelligent chemistry, highlighting neural network potentials, data analysis and spectrum interpretation with artificial-intelligence models, materials design and reaction optimization, and robotic chemists. This collection is accompanied by an invited Editorial written by Prof. Zhenyu Li. We hope readers will enjoy exploring this collection of Comment, Reviews, Perspectives, and Articles.
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This collection features latest research and insights in precision and intelligent chemistry, e.g. AI models, data analysis, materials design, and reaction optimization.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Collection honors Molecular Pharmaceutics Associate Editor Professor Raj Suryanarayanan at the end of his editorial tenure with the journal. The collection illustrates the wide range of impactful research originating from his laboratory. An accompanying editorial by Guest Editor Dr. Paroma Chakravarty introduces the issue.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Profile image of Raj Suryanarayanan on a blue background
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Collection highlights the far-ranging and impactful work of <cite>Molecular Pharmaceutics</cite> Associate Editor Professor Raj Suryanarayan

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Last month, the 2024 Nobel Prize in Medicine was awarded to Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun for the discovery of microRNA and its role in post-transcriptional gene regulation . The understanding of this class of very small RNA molecules has led to new insights on embryonic development and identifying indicators of diseases such as cancer. To honor this year’s recipients, we have put together a collection of articles from across 20 ACS Publications journals dedicated to research in this field.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: the 2024 nobel prize in medicine
virtual_issues.short_blurb: We celebrate the winners of the 2024 Nobel Prize in Medicine with a collection of publications focused on microRNA research.

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Over the past decade, novel microscopies that break the light diffraction limits have continued to develop. These advancements, such as infrared photothermal microscopy, expansion microscopy, SIM, SMLM, and STED microscopy, have truly transformed imaging capabilities, allowing researchers to visualize structures at unprecedented resolution. The integration of data science and AI has further elevated these methods, unlocking deeper insights across diverse research fields.
This Virtual Special Issue, commemorating the 10th anniversary of the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for super-resolved fluorescence microscopy, aims to serve as a critical resource for both current researchers and those entering the field of chemical and biomedical imaging. We hope readers will enjoy exploring this Virtual Special Issue and invite you to read the accompanying Editorial written by Guest Editors Prof. Ji-Xin Cheng, Prof. Tai-Yen Chen, and Associate Editor Prof. Peng Chen.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: An imaging showing a complex mountain range of signals formed by countless colorful pixel blocks
virtual_issues.short_blurb: Explore recent advances in chemical imaging beyond diffraction limits. This Special Issue marks 10 years since the Nobel Prize for super-resolved fluorescence microscopy.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Systems Approaches for Addressing Complex Environmental Problems
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Many of the environmental crises the world now faces have revealed our inability to understand and manage complex systems. We are challenged by dynamic interactions between material and energy flow in the physical systems (i.e., natural and engineered) and the decision/action networks among the social−institutional stakeholders across various scales. The complex systems behind environmental challenges usually involve multiple regions, processes, and environmental media, leading to nonlinear cascading problems across regions, sectors, and environmental media. In this virtual collection, organized jointly by Environmental Science & Technology and Environmental Science & Technology Letters, we consider systems approach as an approach recognizing the key features of complex systems and seeking to characterize and understand the mechanisms and effects of physical−social system interactions and identify the key determinants and strategies to effectively address complex environmental issues.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Collection cover art
virtual_issues.short_blurb: A special collection of articles from ES&T and ES&T Letters on systems approaches to effectively address complex environmental issues.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Many small molecule natural products are known to display potent biological activities, and they have been widely used as human therapeutics and as lead compounds for drug discovery. The three ACS journals, the Journal of Natural Products, ACS Pharmacology & Translational Science, and ACS Infectious Diseases, regularly publish articles that highlight the use of natural products as pharmacology probes or that explore the pharmacological mechanisms of action of bioactive compounds from nature. This Collection of articles and reviews features a sampling of the types of pharmacology-related publications that have appeared in the three journals since the beginning of 2023.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Biologically active natural products
virtual_issues.short_blurb: Natural products bring immense value to drug research and development.

virtual_issues.vi_title: 2024 Rising Stars in Energy and Fuels Research
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Early- and mid-career researchers make up a significant portion of the research workforce and play critical roles in driving knowledge discovery and technological advances in the increasingly globalized research landscape. To celebrate the achievements of researchers who made a significant impact on the Energy field early in their careers, Energy & Fuels has established an annual recognition program. This Special Issue features a collection of papers contributed by the 2024 Energy and Fuels Rising Stars.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Our 29 new Energy and Fuels Rising Stars in Energy Research from 2024
virtual_issues.short_blurb: We celebrate these influential early- and mid-career researchers on their significant impact on various areas of energy research.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: The 9th Congress on Ionic Liquids (COIL-9) was held in April 2023 in Lyon, France with over 300 established and emerging researchers. The conference covered several overarching topics relating to ILs: solvation and separations; interfaces, structure, and dynamics; bio-based materials and pharmaceuticals; functional mate-rials and devices; polymers and polyelectrolytes; bonding, reactivity, and catalysis; electro-chemistry and energy applications; theory and simulation; and properties. Recurring themes in talks included more rational choices of ions incorporating availability and sustainability, the complexity of the systems studied, and many contributions combining experimental and computational research. The numerous papers composing this Virtual Special Issue illustrate the wide scope and vitality of the field of ionic liquids as well as the need for physical chemistry to advance their understanding.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: COIL-9: 9th Congress on Ionic Liquids cover art
virtual_issues.short_blurb: The 9th Congress on Ionic Liquids (COIL-9) showcased the latest physical chemistry developments in fundamental science and applications involving ionic liquids.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Industrial crystallization is widely used in many industries, such as chemical, pharmaceutical, food, and agrochemical. This Virtual Special Issue features some of the latest developments in the field of industrial crystallization, which were discussed at the recent joint International Symposium on Industrial Crystallization and annual meeting of the British Association for Crystal Growth. These topics include specific crystallization phenomena as well as the fundamentals of crystallization mechanisms and processes.

The work in this collection celebrates the innovative and accomplished medicinal chemistry community in the United Kingdom. We encourage the next wave of researchers from the region to submit their original findings, drug annotations, and perspectives to the Journal of Medicinal Chemistry.

In the Future Leaders in Neuroscience collection, the journal wishes to underscore the remarkable potential that each of these early career investigators has brought forward to appreciate the innovative discoveries they have made through these manuscripts.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Celebrate 2024 National Nanotechnology Day with ACS PRF and ACS' Nanotechnology Journals
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Happy National Nanotechnology Day from ACS Petroleum Research Fund (PRF) and ACS Publications! We would like to highlight some of the great research that is funded through ACS PRF and published within ACS Applied Nano Materials, ACS Nano, ACS Nanoscience Au, and Nano Letters.

PRF was established in 1944 and over the years has awarded grants focused on advanced scientific education and fundamental hydrocarbon research. The focus of PRF is around fundamental research in the chemistry, earth sciences, chemical and petroleum engineering, polymers, and materials science.

To celebrate National Nanotechnology Day, we wanted to share some of the research that was funded by ACS PRF and published in ACS journals dedicated to nanotechnology. This collection highlights these articles and the variety of nano research that is funded through ACS PRF.  Happy Nano Day!
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: 2024 National Nanotechnology Day
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This virtual Collection highlights some of the great research that is funded through ACS PRF and published in ACS journals dedicated to nanotechnology.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Two-dimensional materials have attracted tremendous attention in recent years, with transition metal dichalcogenides representing a particularly intriguing class. Their unique layered structures make them suitable for optoelectronic applications such as photodetectors, light-emitting diodes, and solar cells. This thematic issue is dedicated to exploring the latest developments and future directions in the research and application of two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Two-Dimensional Layered Transition Metal Dichalcogenides Cover Image

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Marine ecosystems, from coastal waters to high seas, cover 71% of the Earth’s surface and influence all major biogeochemical cycles, climate regulation and biodiversity conservation. Understanding how marine ecosystems respond to anthropogenic perturbations is therefore of paramount importance and is essential for developing strategies that will maintain critical ecosystem functions across diverse spatial and temporal scales. Environmental Science & Technology and Environmental Science & Technology Letters, as central scientific journals on anthropogenic perturbations of ecosystems, have contributed to the scientific development of marine science in the context of ocean health, as evidenced by this Collection on “Ocean Health”.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A globe representing Earth is encapsulated in a translucent bubble, set against a background of a large ocean wave.
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Collection showcases research that deepens our understanding of how marine ecosystems respond to and are impacted by anthropogenic perturbations.

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Hydrogels are remarkably versatile materials which can be designed with a wide variety of properties, making them suitable for an equally broad range of applications. This Collection from ACS Materials Letters highlights a few recent examples of this versatility from environmental to biomedical applications, as well as demonstrating the advantages of integrating hydrogels with other materials to further expand their functionality.

The Collection also features an Editorial written by ACS Materials Letters Associate Editor, Prof. Grissel Trujillo de Santiago which discusses recent advances in hydrogel engineering and the diverse range of fields where hydrogels find application.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Purple bubbles on a pink background
virtual_issues.short_blurb: A new Collection from ACS Materials Letters showcasing some recent advances in engineering and applications of hydrogels published in the journal.

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Peptide conjugation involves the chemical linkage between peptides (biological or synthetic) and drugs, pro-drugs, or drug-containing nanoparticles. This conjugation can enhance drug efficacy, or facilitate targeting or bioavailability; improvements to pharmacokinetics and reductions in side effects or toxicity have also been observed.

Peptide conjugation methodology has become crucial in the fields of drug delivery, vaccine development, and biotechnology. Bioconjugate Chemistry and Biomacromolecules here showcase the state of the art in peptide conjugation methodology. We continue to welcome research at the interface between peptide conjugation and polymer science, focused on improving biocompatibility, stability, and functionality of bioconjugates towards improving therapeutic applications.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A purple, blue, and teal-green molecular structure over a black background.
virtual_issues.short_blurb: Bioconjugate Chemistry and Biomacromolecules highlight biological peptide conjugates, and the role these molecules play in drug delivery innovations and biotech.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This collection of articles contributed by the colleagues, collaborators, friends, and students of Hiroaki Misawa, Extraordinary Professor at the Research Institute for Electronic Science, Hokkaido University is presented in recognition of his numerous outstanding scientific accomplishments, with a special emphasis on his contributions to photochemistry in general and plasmonic chemistry in particular. Throughout his academic career he welcomed numerous visiting scientists and students from both domestic and foreign institutions to his laboratory, playing a pivotal role in establishing international collaborative relationships with various universities in Taiwan, China, the United States of America, Belgium, Germany, Singapore, and Australia.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Festschrift for Hiroaki Misawa
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This issue includes 49 articles by colleagues of Prof. Misawa as they explore with him the frontiers in photochemistry.

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
In this collection, the Journal of Medicinal Chemistry showcases medicinal chemistry research in Japan with a focus on articles published in the journal between 2020 and 2024. The work in this collection showcases the high quality of medicinal chemistry research in Japan’s industry and academia, and we encourage Japanese companies and universities to submit their high-quality and high-impact medicinal chemistry papers to the Journal of Medicinal Chemistry.

Takayoshi Suzuki, Associate Editor, Journal of Medicinal Chemistry

Haruto Kurata, Editorial Advisory Board, Journal of Medicinal Chemistry

Tomohiko Ohwada, Editorial Advisory Board, Journal of Medicinal Chemistry

Hideyuki Onodera, Editorial Advisory Board, Journal of Medicinal Chemistry

virtual_issues.short_blurb: The <cite>Journal of Medicinal Chemistry</cite> is pleased to introduce a collection on Drug Discovery in Japan, highlighting medicinal chemistry research from this region.

virtual_issues.vi_title: The Next Twenty Years of the Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation
virtual_issues.long_blurb: The <cite>Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation</cite> is celebrating its 20th anniversary in 2024. This curated collection of articles spanning 2005 to 2022 displays the evolution of the scope of the journal.
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This curated collection, spanning 2005 to 2022, displays the evolution of the scope of the journal.

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Solar photovoltaics play a vital role toward the transition to renewable energy and, alongside established silicon-based photovoltaics, we are seeing a range of emerging classes of solar photovoltaic technologies which will facilitate new applications for these technologies. This Collection from JACS Au highlights some recently published work exploring the frontiers of new classes of solar photovoltaics materials.

We hope readers will enjoy exploring this collection of Articles, Letters, and Perspectives and we also encourage you to read the accompanying Editorial written by JACS Au Editorial Advisory Board member, Prof. Justin Hodgkiss.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Rows of solar panels with a purple/blue background
virtual_issues.short_blurb: A new Collection from <cite>JACS Au</cite> showcasing some recent advances in solar photovoltaic materials published in the journal.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Radical Reactions for the Construction and Transformation of Complex Molecules
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
The field of radical chemistry has recently witnessed a revitalization in part due to the advent of modern electrochemistry and photochemistry—including the incorporation of transition metal and organic photocatalysts—, which allow radical reactions to be conducted under milder conditions to provide superior functional group tolerance.

In this Virtual Special Issue, led by Associate Editor Gong Chen and Guest Editors Masayuki Inoue, Lara R. Malins, and Hans Renata, Organic Letters highlights the state of the art in radical reaction development and the strategic incorporation of radical reactions in the construction and modification of small-molecule pharmaceuticals, organic materials, natural products, and large biorelevant molecules.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: An R, containing article TOC figures within, with a dot to its right representing all the radical species publishing in this issue.
virtual_issues.short_blurb: <cite>Organic Letters</cite> highlights the state of the art in radical reaction development and the strategic incorporation of radical reactions in the construction and modification of small-molecule pharmaceuticals, organic materials, natural products, and large biorelevant molecules.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Virtual Special Issue of <cite>Crystal Growth & Design</cite> highlights the latest progress in understanding the link between the properties and structures of nanomaterials. It explores the innovative frontiers of nanomaterials, showcasing groundbreaking advancements in synthesis, characterization, and applications and highlights the salient features and scientific contributions of these studies, each pushing the boundaries of nanotechnology and material science.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Structure-Property Interplay in Nanocrystals Virtual Special Issue Cover Image
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Virtual Special Issue of <cite>Crystal Growth & Design</cite> highlights the latest progress in understanding the link between the properties and structures of nanomaterials.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Recognizing Hispanic and Latinx Analytical Scientists
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Hispanic and Latinx scientists have made substantial contributions to science and technology, spanning a wide range of analytical chemistry fields. In celebration of National Hispanic Heritage month, we highlight Hispanic and Latinx analytical scientists around the world who have recently published in the ACS journals: Analytical Chemistry, the Journal of Proteome Research, ACS Sensors and the Journal of the American Society for Mass Spectrometry. This Collection of articles demonstrates the depth and breadth of current research by Hispanic and Latinx analytical scientists, but more importantly in addition to honoring these published works, we hope this Collection motivates future analytical scientists with these cultural backgrounds to strive to make even more advances in the coming years.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: chemical molecules
virtual_issues.short_blurb: In celebration of National Hispanic Heritage month, we highlight Hispanic and Latinx analytical scientists around the world who have recently published in ACS journals.

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Two-dimensional (2D) materials have attracted enormous interest as a new material planform for exploring fundamental chemistry and physics at the limit of single-atom thickness, and developing totally new technological opportunities beyond the reach of existing materials. Precision chemistry plays a central role in tailoring the atomic and molecular structures of 2D materials, thereby unlocking their full potential in various high-impact areas such as lower-power electronics, energy storage, catalysis, and sensing. This collection of articles from a two-part Precision Chemistry Special Issue features the latest research and perspectives from the leading scientists in this rapidly developing field, highlighting the development and application of precision chemistry for scalable synthesis of 2D materials.

This Special Issue is led by Executive Editor Prof. Xiangfeng Duan, with an introductory Editorial.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Illustration of the precise growth of non-centrosymmetric two-dimensional single crystals, and CuxBi2Se3 nanoplates with systematically tunable Cu doping.
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Special Issue features the latest research and perspectives from the leading scientists in 2D materials, highlighting precision chemistry' role in the field.

virtual_issues.vi_title: 3D Printing Technologies for Environmental and Water Applications
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Three-dimensional (3D) printing is a versatile fabrication technique capable of constructing virtually any geometrically complex object. 3D-printing technologies have been applied to many environmental and water-related applications, such as wastewater treatment, desalination, water splitting, oil–water separation, and environmental detection. In response to this trend, we issued a call for papers in ACS ES&T Water in 2023 to invite researchers to submit their latest advances in the use of 3D printed technologies in water treatment and environmental protection applications.

We are honored and delighted to publish this latest research as a new special issue entitled “3D Printing Technologies for Environmental and Water Applications". The special issue showcases the latest advancements and challenges encountered in applying 3D-printing technologies to address environmental and water-related issues, including water treatment via adsorption, photocatalysis, advanced oxidation processes, environmental detection, the design of environmental devices, and membrane separations.

We hope you enjoy this special issue collection of the latest research on this topic and that it inspires future ideas and innovation to further utilize this technology in water quality and environmental protection research.

Sheng Guo, Wuhan Textile University, China
Yifu Ding, University of Colorado Boulder, USA
Kun Zhou, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: 3D printing technologies applied to water quality and environmental protection research
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This special issue showcases the latest research in the application of 3D printing technologies in water quality and environmental protection research.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Biocatalysis in Asia and the Pacific
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Biocatalysis has become a key area of research across a range of fields, with its increasing adoption in areas such as organic synthesis and pharmaceutical research driven by the need for more sustainable chemical technologies and processes. This interest in new green technologies has led to a substantial increase in fundamental research in biocatalysis in the Asia and Pacific regions in particular, with researchers from a wide range of disciplines entering the field in recent years. This Virtual Special Issue from JACS Au captures the breadth of research in biocatalysis in Asia and the Pacific and showcases the level of engagement from a very diverse group of scientists.

This Virtual Special Issue is led by an introductory Editorial written by Associate Editor Prof. Sabine Flitsch and guest editors Prof. Nicholas Turner and Prof. Zhi Li.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Map of Asia and the Pacific region with biological molecule structures on green background
virtual_issues.short_blurb: A Virtual Special Issue from <cite>JACS Au</cite> showcasing some recently published innovations in biocatalysis research from the Asia and Pacific region.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Operando and In Situ Studies in Catalysis and Electrocatalysis
virtual_issues.long_blurb: In this virtual thematic issue, we provide a comprehensive overview of recent advancements in in situ and operando studies in thermal catalysis and electrocatalysis. Additionally, we offer insights into future developments in this field. Catalysts are inherently dynamic materials, capable of undergoing transformations in response to various environmental factors or stimuli such as temperature, pressure, electrical potential, gas and/or liquid composition, and reaction time. These fluctuations profoundly influence the interactions between the catalyst and the gas and liquid phase, thereby influencing the surface and bulk structure and properties of the catalytic material. It is thus paramount to grasp this intricate interplay to facilitate a knowledge-driven exploration of novel catalytic materials, pinpointing structural features directly pertinent to catalytic activity while pushing the boundaries of time and spatial resolutions.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Operando and In Situ Studies in Catalysis and Electrocatalysis Cover Image

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This virtual thematic issue of <cite>Chemical Reviews</cite> aims to discuss how the concept of molecular crowding has evolved within the last two decades, touching new complementary territories, and also as a result of the introduction of new approaches employed in crowding studies which have offered further potentialities to study crowding.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Molecular Crowding Cover Image

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This virtual thematic issue invites several prestigious scientists to present the recent advances achieved in ILs for diverse applications, covering such areas as the properties of ILs (viscosity and biotoxicity), intelligent design and simulation (computer-aided ILs design, process simulation, and optimization of ILs), efficient synthesis and reaction catalysis (microwave-assisted IL technology and ILs catalysts), the application in separation processes (gas separation, liquid–liquid extraction, and separation of fluorocarbon refrigerant mixtures), the application in biopharmaceuticals (active pharmaceutical ingredients, protein solvents, and excipients), the applications in energy storage, and the ILs with new properties (magnetic ILs, polymerized ILs and colloidal ILs, and ILs supported on metal–organic frameworks).
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Ionic Liquids for Diverse Applications Cover Image

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Perovskites are a broad class of materials that have interesting crystal structures and properties that are potentially important for a number of applications. A major focus of this Virtual Special Issue is the use of organic-inorganic hybrid metal halide perovskites in solar cells. Perovskites solar cells have shown spectacular conversion efficiencies; however, many issues affect their suitability for consumer products. Therefore, fundamental understanding of perovskite materials including the dynamics and structure of the photogenerated charge carriers is critical for the future viability of perovskites in photovoltaic and optoelectronic devices such as LEDs and photodetectors.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A stylistic image of the molecular makeup of perovskites
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This issue captures fundamental and applied studies of perovskites, providing a helpful tool in navigating the variety and depth of research on these fascinating materials.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Professor Gregory A. Voth, through his research, has dramatically advanced our understanding of the structure and dynamics of complex condensed phase systems, ranging from ionic liquids to viral capsids, while addressing both classical and quantal aspects of these phenomena. He has invented and developed a vast array of powerful computational methods for effectively modeling such systems that once seemed intractable. To celebrate Dr. Voth’s accomplishments in biological, chemical, and material science as well as the clear thinking, creativity, physical insights, and big-picture vision he has passed along to his mentees, his friends and colleagues have organized and provided articles for this Festschrift.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A collage of science-related icons
virtual_issues.short_blurb: Gregory Voth has made numerous groundbreaking contributions that have advanced our understanding of complex condensed phase systems. This Festschrift honors his 65th birthday.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Emissions, Chemistry, and the Environmental Impacts of Wildland Fire
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Wildland fires are increasing in frequency globally due to local and global climate conditions and human activities related to land use change.  Wildland fires are one of the largest sources of pollutants to the global atmosphere with serious impacts on air quality, air chemistry and climate.  Wildland fires also result in significant environmental impacts including habitat destruction, wildlife and biodiversity impacts, water quality decline and human and environmental health impacts.  
Nearly half a century of wildland fire emissions research exists.  However, due to the complex emissions chemistry of wildland fires key data gaps remain.  With climate change increasingly driving higher fire activity, the need to understand the full environmental and health impacts of wildland fires will continue to increase in importance.  
To shine a spotlight on current research trends on this important topic in collaboration with ACS ES&T Air, we have curated this collection of recently published papers back through 2019 in ES&T, ES&T Letters, and ACS ES&T Water related to wildland fire research.  This collection showcases some of the breadth and complexity of wildland fire research, covering wildland fire emissions, impacts on the wildland/urban interface, brown carbon production, the atmospheric evolution of wildland fire smoke, source apportionment studies, impacts on human health and ecosystems, and advances in smoke modelling.  
We hope you enjoy this curated collection and that it helps inform and inspire future research in this important area of air chemistry and environmental research.  

Amara Holder (US EPA) and Amy Sullivan (Colorado State University)
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Wildland fire smoke generation and impacts on air quality to nearby cities and rural areas, and the water quality of nearby water bodies.
virtual_issues.short_blurb: Read about the latest advancements in understanding the impacts of wildland fire on human health, ecosystems, and climate.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Highlighting 2023 Contributions from our Editorial Board Members
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
This Special Issue highlights the research articles contributed by our Editors and our Editorial Advisory Board members in 2023. The 87 articles included illustrate the breath and commitment of the best ambassadors of Langmuir.

We encourage our readers to browse through this list to find papers that interest you and to be inspired by our Editorial Board members.
