virtual_issues.short_blurb: This Special Issue highlights the research articles contributed in 2023 by the best ambassadors of <cite>Langmuir</cite>, our Editors and Editorial Advisory Board members.

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Planetary Boundaries are limits that define the safe operating space to allow for the sustainability of human society. It is a concept and strategy that has developed over the past 15 years as scientists identify threats that could imperil Earth systems and society as we know it today, and how to address them sustainably. Nine Planetary Boundaries have been considered: Climate change, ocean acidification, stratospheric ozone, biogeochemical nitrogen cycle and phosphorus cycle, global freshwater use, land system change, biodiversity loss, novel entities (formerly chemical pollution) and atmospheric aerosol loading. Transgressing one or more of these Planetary Boundaries may be deleterious or even catastrophic due to the risk of crossing thresholds that will trigger non-linear, abrupt environmental change.

More recently, the Earth Commission further developed the concept into a set of Safe and Just Earth System Boundaries (ESBs), defining limits not only for maintaining a stable and resilient Earth system (i.e. safe boundaries), but also to minimize harm to humans (i.e. just boundaries). The new ESBs are intended to provide the world with a viable corridor to transition to sustainable practices. Currently, the Safe and Just ESBs have been quantified for climate, the biosphere, fresh water, nutrients, and aerosols at global and sub-global scales.

Currently, the Earth Commission 2.0 is working on redefining the Safe and Just ESBs of those already set by considering interactions between boundaries and inevitable trade-offs that will be needed, to translate the Safe and Just ESBs into actionable targets, and to chart transformation pathways so that societies can pull back from exceeding the boundaries. Earth Commission 2.0 is also tackling the difficult question of setting Safe and Just ESBs for novel entities. Because boundaries alone are insufficient to bring about change, Earth Commission 2.0 is also tasked with developing the transformative pathways for societies to stay within the boundaries for novel entities.

To support this effort and shine a spotlight on recent research on the Planetary Boundaries, particularly in the chemical pollution or ‘novel entity’ space, we have curated this Collection of recently published papers from Environmental Science & Technology and Environmental Science & Technology Letters entitled ‘Transgressing Earth System Boundaries’. We hope you enjoy this special Collection and it inspires further research in this crucial area of defining and maintaining a sustainable Earth.

Professor Miriam Diamond (University of Toronto, Canada) and Zhanyun Wang (EMPA, Switzerland)
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: distorted image of the earth
virtual_issues.short_blurb: A special collection of articles from <cite>ES&T Letters</cite> and <cite>ES&T</cite> on Earth System Boundaries with special focus on Novel Entities (chemical pollution)

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
The ever-broadening structural diversity and remarkable adsorption, separation, and catalytic properties of Zeolites make them a critically important class of materials with a range of applications. As new structures with enhanced functionality are being discovered, this pool of applications continues to expand. In this Collection, the editors at Chemistry of Materials highlight some advances in this exciting and continually growing field that have recently been published in the journal.

Leading the Collection is a guest Editorial written by Prof. Jihong Yu which discusses the future of the field, and an Editorial written by Editor-in-Chief, Prof. Sara Skrabalak which provides an introduction to the articles which feature.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Pink and off-white crystals of varying sizes
virtual_issues.short_blurb: A new Collection from Chemistry of Materials highlighting some recent advances in synthesis, characterization, and applications of Zeolites, a critically important and ever-expanding class of materials.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Investigating the Uses and Impacts of Generative Artificial Intelligence in Chemistry Education
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
This VSI highlights the emerging applications of generative artificial intelligence (AI) in chemistry education. An accompanying editorial by the Guest Editor Team introduces the VSI.

Guest Editors Elizabeth Yuriev, Monash University, Australia
Donald J. Wink, University of Illinois at Chicago, USA
Thomas A. Holme, Iowa State University, USA
virtual_issues.short_blurb: <cite>The Journal of Chemical Education</cite> is pleased to present a Virtual Special Issue highlighting the emerging applications of generative artificial intelligence (AI) in chemistry education.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Over the past decade, it has become abundantly clear that there is no escaping the emerging growth of artificial intelligence (AI) in every facet of our lives. The advanced algorithms and modeling approaches grouped under this "AI" umbrella empower us to use data to build predictive models for complex phenomena and apply these models in generative contexts to make suggestions or recommendations. Simultaneously, social scientists are grasping the ethical, legal, and societal implications of this exponential growth of AI in various aspects of our lives. As Associate Editors of Macromolecules and active researchers in AI and machine learning (ML) for polymer science, it is clear to us that the field of polymer science is lagging behind most other areas of chemistry in adopting and applying AI tools. Specifically, the fields of inorganic chemistry, nanomaterials, biomedical imaging, and bioinformatics are farther ahead in leveraging the power of AI and ML. We believe this may be because our field presents many unique challenges that prevent the AI tools developed in other areas of chemistry from being directly translated to polymer science, some of which we address in this Collection.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A chemical structure emerges from a laptop screen
virtual_issues.short_blurb: See the very latest in artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques applied to polymer science, published in Macromolecules.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Advances in Small and Large Molecule Pharmaceutics Research across Ireland
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
This virtual special issue of Molecular Pharmaceutics is dedicated to pharmaceutics research on the island of Ireland. Ireland has a strong tradition of research excellence in pharmaceutics, with a focus on developing innovative solutions for drug delivery and formulation. In Ireland, the pharmaceutical industry is a key contributor to the economy, with several major multinational companies operating in the country. An editorial written by the Guest Editors introduces the VSI.

Guest Editors
Gavin Andrews, Queen's University of Belfast
Anne Marie Healy, Trinity College Dublin
Elizabeth Topp, Purdue University and National Institute for Bioprocessing Research and Training, Dublin
virtual_issues.short_blurb: This virtual special issue highlights the strong tradition of research excellence in pharmaceutics from the island of Ireland.

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
As we strive to make the transition away from a reliance on fossil fuels, the development of next-generation energy systems is critical. Green hydrogen production through catalytic water splitting is a leading technology toward achieving this goal and as such is a thriving and fast-moving area of research for materials scientists. This Virtual Special Issue from ACS Materials Letters showcases some state-of-the-art innovations in materials design for this vital application recently published in the journal.

This Virtual Special Issue is led by an introductory Editorial written by Associate Editor Prof. Yujie Xiong.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Blue background with water bubbles
virtual_issues.short_blurb: A Virtual Special Issue from ACS Material Letters highlighting recent developments in materials and system design for water splitting.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Studies have shown that CO<sub>2</sub> can be safely stored underground, such as in deep, porous rock formations, to solve issues related to carbon emissions. Formation rocks have the capacity to store carbon emissions depending on rock type, depth, and fluids contained in the rock. Trapping potential is influenced by numerous factors, including geochemical and geomechanical effects and the associated seal integrity. The articles presented in this virtual special issue highlight high-quality research from the scientific community in the field of CO<sub>2</sub> geostorage.

In this collection, <cite>ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters</cite> has compiled an online profile series which highlights the contributions of medicinal chemists from both academic and industrial backgrounds. In this collection, you will explore how medicinal chemistry research efforts within industry and academia have changed and evolved over the last few years and the many new exciting research areas that have emerged or been re-energized. We hope that you enjoy this collection and are energized for a discussion on the future of medicinal chemistry!
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: futuristic looking background with pills

virtual_issues.vi_title: Proteins for Developing Applied and Functional Materials
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Shifting from a petroleum-based plastic society to a newer one built on circular economy principles requires maximizing the use of renewable resources and resolving the challenges that come with their use. Biopolymers have taken an important role in the design of bio-based materials with functional properties, especially those derived from biomass available at a large scale. Recent studies have shown how proteins have taken a new dimension in developing functional materials, taking a step forward from their traditional use in food and biomedicine. By correlating the amino acidic profile of proteins at the nanoscale with their thermomechanical properties at the macroscale enables us to translate these precision polymers into a versatile design of materials, targeting large-scale applications such as foams and food packaging. Moreover, the advances in understanding proteins from a bottom-up perspective reached promising achievements for their use in applications that were not foreseen before, including biosensors, optoelectronics and semiconductors.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A multicolored protein showing the molecule's secondary structure over a black background

virtual_issues.vi_title: Machine Learning in Physical Chemistry Volume 2
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Our second Virtual Special Issue on Machine Learning covers an enormous amount of thought-provoking new ground in the development and use of new tools for advancing physical chemistry research. It explores the development of new methods, innovative use of existing methods, and application of ML/AI and other data-driven models to a wide variety of topics covering all sections of <cite>JPC A/B/C</cite>. The 79 invited papers featured below illustrate the relevance and popularity of this area of research, which we expect will continue to expand at an impressive rate. We are grateful to the community of authors who have contributed to this important body of work and we look forward to future submissions in this area.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: An artistic rendering of an advanced computer core

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Prof. C. N. R. Rao has led a remarkable career spanning seven decades in which he has been a pioneering figure in solid-state and materials chemistry. As Prof. Rao celebrated his 90th on June 30th, 2024, this Virtual Special Issue celebrates his immense contributions to materials chemistry and profound impact on the scientific community at large, dating back to the publication of his first research article in 1954. It is a testament to the esteem and affection in which he is held that we have been able to compile a collection of over 60 articles for this Virtual Special Issue, with further contributions still to come.

This collection is led by an Editorial written by guest editors, Profs. Dipankar Sarma, Ashok Ganguli, Bettina Lotsch, and Patrick Woodward.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: photo of Prof. C. N. R. Rao

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This collection of The <cite>Journal of Chemical Education</cite> marks the seventh Festschrift since the program was begun in 2021. This Festschrift collects 37 articles from leading authors in Chemistry Education that touch on themes in the teaching and learning of chemistry that have been advanced by the scholarship of Professor Diane Bunce of Catholic University of America and the United States Naval Academy. The articles are organized along a progression of ideas related to conducting Chemical Education Research (CER), an area of scholarship the Prof. Bunce championed throughout her career. The first section addresses ways new investigators can get started doing CER work. The second section considers CER studies in settings with relatively small class sizes and the third section collects articles that describe CER projects carried out in large classroom settings where statistical treatments of quantitative data are appropriate. In addition to articles about studies from her own research group, her contributions to the <cite>Journal of Chemical Education</cite> include serving as the first Associate Editor for manuscripts describing CER studies. The Journal is happy to have the ability to honor Prof. Bunce for her contributions to CER and her mentorship of others learning to conduct such work.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Profile image of Diane Bunce

virtual_issues.vi_title: Celebrating the 25th Anniversary of the Chemical Research Society in India
virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Special Collection in <cite>JACS</cite> aims to curate high-impact, significant contributions from India spanning a wide spectrum of interdisciplinary areas over the past 25 years. From Chemical Biology to Theoretical Chemistry, Supramolecular Chemistry to Materials Science, Energy, and Environment, these articles clearly point out the breadth and depth of Indian scientific ingenuity. We believe that initiatives like this strengthen the enduring partnership between the American Chemical Society and CRSI, fostering greater collaboration and synergy in advancing scientific knowledge and discovery.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Celebrating the 25th Anniversary of the Chemical Research Society in India

virtual_issues.long_blurb: In this Collection, we highlight some of the most impactful articles in the journal as reflected by citations in 2023. Highly cited articles provide insight into which research topics are attracting the most attention and reflect innovative new discoveries, or timely reviews and perspectives on areas of contemporary interest. An accompanying editorial by the Editor-in-Chief introduces the issue.

In this collection, the <cite>Journal of Medicinal Chemistry</cite> showcases medicinal chemistry research in South America with a focus on articles published in the journal between 2020 and 2024. The work in this collection highlights the dedicated medicinal chemistry community in South America and hopes to encourage more landmark research from this region in the years to come.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Outline of South America

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Phytochemicals have become an attractive topic for researchers in chemistry in recent years, due to growing evidence of the beneficial effects to our health from consumption of carotenoids, polyphenols, isoprenoids, phytosterols, saponins, dietary fibers, polysaccharides, etc. This <cite>ACS Omega</cite> Virtual Special Issue highlights high-quality research in phytochemistry, with a focus on chemical characterization of characterization of phytochemicals. Topics include Novel extraction techniques for phytochemicals, Encapsulation of phytochemicals, Changes in phytochemicals during processing, Effects of biotic and abiotic stresses on phytochemicals, Bioaccessibility and bioavailability of phytochemicals, Effect of food matrix on the content and bioavailability of phytochemicals, Phytochemicals obtained from food wastes.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: This ACS Omega Virtual Special Issue highlights high-quality research in phytochemistry, with a focus on chemical characterization of phytochemicals.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Celebrating the 25th Anniversary of the Chemical Research Society in India
virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Special Collection in <cite>JACS</cite> aims to curate high-impact, significant contributions from India spanning a wide spectrum of interdisciplinary areas over the past 25 years. From Chemical Biology to Theoretical Chemistry, Supramolecular Chemistry to Materials Science, Energy, and Environment, these articles clearly point out the breadth and depth of Indian scientific ingenuity. We believe that initiatives like this strengthen the enduring partnership between the American Chemical Society and CRSI, fostering greater collaboration and synergy in advancing scientific knowledge and discovery.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Celebrating the 25th Anniversary of the Chemical Research Society in India

virtual_issues.vi_title: Highlights of the 4th International Symposium of Food Science and Nutrition Health in Dalian, China
virtual_issues.long_blurb: The 4th International Symposium of Food Science and Nutrition Health was held from May 29-31, 2023 in Dalian, China. The symposium explored 'The Great Food Perspective' under the theme 'Focusing on new discoveries in food technology and creating a new future of nutrition and health' and was attended by over 1000 scientists from more than 100 institutions around the world. This virtual special issue highlights a selection of articles from contributions at the conference.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Aerial view of Dalian, China at night-time

virtual_issues.long_blurb: World Microbiome Day, which is held on June 27th every year, raises awareness to the importance of the microbiome and its role in human health and disease, and the environment we live in. ACS Publications put forth its first World Microbiome Day Collection in 2023. In this 2024 Collection, you will find contributions from 25 ACS journals highlighting the latest achievements in microbiome research.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: microbiomes

virtual_issues.long_blurb: In this Collection, we have intentionally opened two distinct, but related, fields associated with the magneto-responsive and spin-responsive behavior of macromolecular systems. While the materials design paradigms for enhanced performance in either of these end-use spaces is distinct, there are clear points of synergy in coupling these avenues of research. Importantly, this Collection aims to stress the foundational principles associated with the chemistry, physics, and materials science of the polymers. While it is not unlikely that structure-property relationship formulation could involve device fabrication and testbed characterization, works in this Collection will not include manuscripts whose primary intellectual merit is centered on device fabrication or performance optimization.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A black background with blue lines denoting a magnetic field banded across the foreground

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
High-entropy materials occupy a unique compositional space which brings forward a range of useful properties for various applications, which keeps them at the forefront of material chemistry. In this joint Collection, the editors of Chemistry of Materials, ACS Materials Letters, and ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces, and ACS Materials Au have highlighted a selection of pioneering contributions to this exciting field which we hope inspire future study and further innovation.

This Collection also features an Editorial written by Chemistry of Materials and ACS Materials Letters Editor-in-Chief, Prof. Sara Skrabalak, ACS Materials Letters Associate Editor, Prof. Yujie Xiong, and ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces Associate Editor, Prof. Zhengtang Luo.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: high entropy materials

virtual_issues.long_blurb: The Fourteenth International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA) brought together researchers from the synthetic biology, systems biology, and design automation communities to discuss concepts, methodologies, and software tools for the computational analysis and synthesis of biological systems.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A monotone image of traffic circling l'Arc de Triomphe in Paris.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Welcome to this Special Issue that aims to incorporate a broad range of observational, laboratory and theoretical techniques that combine to make this such a vibrant, diverse, and stimulating field of study. Our main focus in this Issue is to present cutting edge research studies, including the presentation of novel experimental and analytical methods, chemical kinetic models, observational studies, and quantum chemical approaches, to promote a deeper understanding of how and where chemical complexity may arise in planetary environments.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: planetary environments

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Attosecond (10<sup>-18</sup> s) science provides access to the natural time scale of electronic motion in matter and was recently recognized by the 2023 Nobel Prize in Physics. Chemistry, i.e., the breaking and formation of bonds, is dictated by electron dynamics and accompanying nuclear motion and thus is an area ripe for study using ultrafast methods. High-harmonic generation (HHG) sources and X-ray free electron lasers (XFELs) can now routinely generate light pulses of sub-femtosecond duration, thus providing access to the attosecond time scale for both visualization and control of electron dynamics. The articles in this Virtual Special Issue present some of the most recent experimental and theoretical advances on the application of the concepts and tools of attosecond science to molecular systems, thus showing the increasing interest in attosecond chemistry and providing guidelines for future investigations.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Stylized molecular orbitals.

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Wastewater surveillance of infectious disease targets, or wastewater-based epidemiology (WBE), has emerged as a disruptive, powerful method to understand community disease occurrence. The scientific advances, rapid scaling, and translation for public health within the WBE field over the last 4 years is unprecedented. WBE is now routinely used to inform public health decision making on a wide range of infectious diseases including COVID-19, influenza, respiratory syncytial virus, and more.

This collection of recently published papers from across the ES&T family of journals highlights some of the most important advances in WBE that have accelerated innovation and translation of this technology. We have included papers that have contributed to methodologies for measuring infectious disease targets in wastewater, insights into fate and transport of the targets in wastewater, and models that relate concentrations of the targets in wastewater to disease occurrence. In addition, we have included foundational papers that establish and validate WBE for a wide range of infectious disease targets from SARS-CoV-2 to influenza to Candida auris and Dengue virus.

We hope the curated collection inspires additional highly creative work in this area.

Professor Alexandria Boehm (Stanford University, USA) and Dr. Tim Julian (Eawag, Switzerland)

virtual_issues.vi_title: Advanced Materials and Processes for Building Low-Carbon Energy Systems
virtual_issues.long_blurb: This collection highlights advances in the material and process development devoted to enhancing clean energy production, storage, and conversion, all aimed at fostering a sustainable, low-carbon future.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Advanced Materials and Processes for Building Low-Carbon Energy Systems

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Collection compiles Viewpoints, Energy Focus and Perspectives, published in <cite>ACS Energy Letters</cite> by experts in electrochemical energy storage. The articles included in this collection aim to shed light on emerging trends and best practices within the field and can serve as an excellent resource for wide range of researchers from academia to industry.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: electrochemical energy storage systems

virtual_issues.long_blurb: In recent decades, the fields of physical chemistry and related disciplines have experienced significant expansion in China. This growth can be attributed to strategic investments in both basic science and applied research areas, including solar cells and catalysis. The research landscape has been significantly enriched and diversified by the increasing participation of women. They have remained steadfast, continuing their remarkable upward trajectory, and inspiring the next generation of scientists. In this Virtual Special we celebrate their scientific contributions and advances with a curated collection of 75 articles by nationally and internationally recognized female Chinese scholars.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A woman scientist looking at a beaker

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
This VSI highlights the use of machine learning in support of statistical mechanics-based methods for computation of thermophysical properties and phase equilibria. An accompanying editorial by the Guest Editor Team introduces the VSI.

Guest Editors
Rose Cersonsky, University of Wisconsin-Madison
Bingqing Cheng, Institute of Science and Technology Austria
David Kofke, University of Buffalo
Erich A. Muller, Imperial College London
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: thermophysical properties and machine learning

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This collection of <cite>The Journal of Chemical Education</cite> marks the sixth Festschrift since the program was begun in 2021. This Festschrift collects 43 articles from leading authors in Chemistry Education that touch on themes in the teaching and learning of chemistry that have been advanced by the scholarship of Professor David F. Treagust of Curtin University. Five different areas of student learning of chemistry inform the themes incorporated in this collection. They include (1) student understanding of chemical equilibrium; (2) laboratory learning and the influence of on-line technologies; (3) the role of multiple representations in student learning about chemicals; (4) the challenges students have learning about chemical bonding; and (5) the development and use of diagnostic testing instruments to inform the teaching of chemistry. Prof. Treagust has been an international leader in scholarship related to these themes, as well as others. The Journal is happy to have the ability to honor Prof. Treagust for his contributions to the field, and his contributions to the Journal.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Profile image of Professor David F. Treagust

virtual_issues.vi_title: Highly Cited Articles of the Past Decade
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
In 2024, ACS Infectious Diseases is celebrating 10 years of publishing infectious diseases research. In this collection, we showcase a selection of the most influential and cited articles of the past decade. We collected the top three cited articles from each year since the inaugural year of the journal in 2014.

The articles in this collection encompass a wide breadth of topical areas of research performed by the infectious diseases community including antibacterial drug discovery, antiviral therapeutics, mechanism of action, detection and diagnosis of infectious diseases, vaccines, host-pathogen interactions, antimicrobial polymeric and nanomaterials, etc. We hope you will enjoy this collection and help us celebrate 10 years of ACS Infectious Diseases!
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Highly Cited Articles of the Past Decade cover image for ACS Infectious Diseases

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Wearable devices, including smart watches, virtual reality glasses, skin patches, and smart garments, just to name a few, are becoming increasingly visible in human society. They track critical physiological parameters for health surveillance and athletic performance assessment; they continuously monitor biomarkers for chronic disease management; they also collect body information and deliver stimulation for seamless human–machine interaction.

Contemporary research endeavors are directed toward the development of devices that are thinner, smaller, softer, and more stretchable. Such advancement promises to unlock a number of previously unattainable applications. Given the convergence of multiple disciplines and research domains required to advance this field, wearable device research is inherently multidisciplinary, interdisciplinary, and transdisciplinary. While it is impossible to cover all the topics, this virtual thematic issue brings together leaders in the field of diverse backgrounds to discuss recent advancements, trends, and future directions for wearable devices.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: In the cover art, the left half-human wears a smart light-emitting patch, which wirelessly collects and displays cardiac signals from a wearable bio-stamp on the chest, while the right half-humanoid wears an artificial vision device that detects, processes, and uploads pre-processed visual data for cloud computing.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Special Issue is a collaboration between the <cite>Journal of the American Society for Mass Spectrometry (JASMS)</cite> and the Korean Society for Mass Spectrometry (KSMS) and showcases high-quality research published by authors in the Asia-Oceania region. The Special Issue was managed by <cite>JASMS</cite> Associate Editor Richard O’Hair with Guest Editor Byungjoo Kim (President of the KSMS).
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: asia oceania

virtual_issues.long_blurb: The ACS Division of Agrochemicals (AGRO) recently celebrated its 50th anniversary. Formed in 1970, AGRO supports "Chemistry For and From Agriculture". A worldwide community of scientists and stakeholders to advance knowledge and promote innovative solutions for the protection of agricultural productivity, public health, and the environment. To honor the first 50 years of AGRO, this virtual special issue highlights approximately 50 new and previously published articles from the <cite>Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry</cite> and its companion journal <cite>ACS Agricultural Science and Technology</cite>. This collection includes a sampling of many highly cited contributions from winners of AGRO sponsored awards and highlights the diversity of interests and topics of the AGRO community. The virtual special issue also celebrates a fruitful partnership between AGRO and <cite>Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry</cite>.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: argo division 50th anniversary

virtual_issues.vi_title: Multiscale Modeling and Artificial Intelligence for Multiphase Flow Science
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Multiphase reactors are vital components in various industries, including chemical, petroleum, pharmaceutical, food, and environmental sectors. Understanding the complex behaviours within these reactors, involving phenomena like flow dynamics, mass and heat transfer, and chemical reactions, is crucial for effective process design and control. These phenomena occur at different scales and are interrelated, necessitating the study of flow, transport, and reactions at multiple scales. <cite>I&ECR</cite> present this Special Issue to highlight research focused on this important area.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: The fusion of artificial intelligence with multiscale modeling has opened a new avenue to improve the understanding of multiphase flow science.

virtual_issues.vi_title: MDMA: Neurochemical Perspectives on a Potential Breakthrough Therapy
virtual_issues.long_blurb: On June 4, 2024, the FDA's Psychopharmacologic Drugs Advisory Committee will convene to review Lykos Therapeutics' midomafetamine (MDMA) capsules, marking a potentially historic milestone in the treatment of PTSD - the first time in 25 years that a new therapy for PTSD has been considered by the committee. In conjunction with this pivotal event, <cite>ACS Chemical Neuroscience</cite> is highlighting a special collection of articles exploring the diverse aspects of MDMA's science—from its potential for neurotoxicity in developmental models to its unique effects on the serotonin system. This curated collection serves not only as a repository of scientific inquiry but also as a bridge connecting the public and scientific community to both key historic and new research ahead of MDMA's potential FDA approval.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Text reading MDMA: Neurochemical Perspectives on a Potential Breakthrough Therapy on abstract background

virtual_issues.vi_title: Angel Irabien Festschrift: Honoring His Impact on the Profession
virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Special Issue is dedicated to Professor Angel Irabien from the Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering at the Universidad of Cantabria in Spain. He is an international leader on low carbon technologies, carbon dioxide conversion, and assessment of environmental impact of products and processes. We present 16 articles addressing a variety of problems in the general area of sustainability, to celebrate Prof. Angel Irabien’s interests. The guest editors of this Special Issue would like to thank all the authors who contributed to it, and the editorial team of ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering and its referees who made it possible.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Irabien looking at the camera, outdoors, olive green sweater, with arms crossed

virtual_issues.long_blurb: International Day of Action for Women’s Health is recognized on May 28<sup>th</sup> to raise awareness for diseases and conditions that affect women’s physical and emotional health. In this Collection, the <cite>Journal of Medicinal Chemistry</cite> showcases 17 articles that address the ongoing research dedicated to the unmet medical needs in women’s healthcare. This Collection supports a greater understanding of the diseases and issues that affect mostly women, and acknowledges the barriers faced by those who research in this field.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Women’s Health image

virtual_issues.vi_title: Materials for Fuel Cells and Water Electrolysis
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Hydrogen fuel cells and water electrolyzers have become a critical area of research toward more sustainable energy production. This Collection of papers published in JACS Au highlights a range of recent advances in this highly active research area, including the development of catalytic materials and membranes, interfacial behavior analysis, and the design of single cells.

We hope readers will enjoy exploring this collection of Articles, Letters, and Perspectives and we also encourage you to read the accompanying Editorial written by JACS Au Associate Editor, Prof. Hyunjoo Lee.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Hydrogen fuel cell used to charge two electric cars and power a home on a purple background

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This collection highlights recent <cite>Bioconjugate Chemistry</cite> publications from authors working in industry. Curated by <cite>Bioconjugate Chemistry</cite> Topic Editor Apoorva Sarode (Genentech Inc.), this collection is comprised of innovative research from several industrial pathways, including National Laboratories, Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical companies, and startups.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Cartoon figures in lab coats and scrubs, holding pills and looking into microscopes

virtual_issues.vi_title: 101 years of Chemistry Everywhere: Outreach and Chemical Education
virtual_issues.long_blurb: The Journal of Chemical Education is pleased to present a Collection highlighting contributions to the journal illustrating the many ways that chemistry can be shared with the public. An accompanying editorial by the Editor-in-Chief introduces the collection.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: 101 years of Chemistry Everywhere: Outreach and Chemical Education collection cover art

virtual_issues.vi_title: Celebrating the International Day of Light - 2024
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Photonics plays a pivotal role in science and technology on a broad scale, enabling new innovations in communication and information processing, sensing and imaging, materials and device design, energy and sustainability, and fundamental science. This curated Collection commemorates The International Day of Light in 2024 and features recent, highly-cited articles from <cite>ACS Photonics</cite> that encompass these topical areas.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: international day of light

virtual_issues.vi_title: Nucleic Acids: A 70th Anniversary Celebration of DNA
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Recently we crossed two important milestones in the field of nucleic acids research. Firstly, the 100th anniversary of the birth of Har Gobind Khorana (1922-2011) whose pioneering work on the genetic code and its deciphering laid the foundation for the development of modern biotechnology and genetic engineering. Har Gobind Khorana shared the 1968 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine with Marshall W. Nirenberg and Robert W. Holley for his research on the genetic code and its interpretation by cells. In subsequent years, he developed his understanding even further by synthesizing RNA fragments of a known sequence and determining the corresponding amino acid sequence of the protein they encoded. His work was founded on the publication 70 years ago of the double-helical structure of Deoxyribose Nucleic Acid by James Watson and Francis Crick. This discovery, along with the key contribution by Maurice Wilkins and Rosalind Franklin, is widely regarded as one of the most significant scientific breakthroughs of the 20th century. The articles presented in this virtual special issue serve as representative samples, albeit not exhaustive, of how the synthesis and structure of DNA have profoundly influenced areas further afield.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: DNA

virtual_issues.long_blurb: The Editorial Advisory Board (EAB) is an essential steering group for Molecular Pharmaceutics and is made up of prominent pharmaceutical scientists from around the globe. Their published work, some of which is highlighted in this collection, pushes the boundary of knowledge, addressing current and future challenges in drug delivery. An editorial by the Editor-in-Chief of the journal introduces the EAB and the Collection.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Plant Biotechnology, Molecular Breeding, and Food Security
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Food security is facing severe challenges as the global population rapidly increases. To meet the food demands of the growing population, greater and more consistent crop production must be achieved. With the rapid progress of plant biotechnology, plant breeding has entered a new and more efficient era of molecular breeding. Important traits such as yield, quality, abiotic/biotic resistance, and nitrogen use efficiency (NUE) have been significantly improved and thus the global food security crisis has been eased to some extent. This virtual special issue aims to summarize and promote the development of plant biotechnology, molecular breeding and their applications in improving crop varieties to ensure food security.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: plant biotechnology, molecular breeding and food security

virtual_issues.vi_title: Celebrating the 60th Anniversary of the MIKIW Meeting-in-Miniature
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
The MIKIW Meeting-in-Miniature is an annual medicinal chemistry conference hosted by the Departments of Medicinal Chemistry/Pharmaceutical Sciences at the Universities of Minnesota, Illinois-Chicago, Kansas, Iowa, and Wisconsin. ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters and the Journal of Medicinal Chemistry are recognizing the 60th anniversary of the MIKIW Meeting-in-Miniature with this Virtual Special Issue. We hope you enjoy this collection and look forward to many more years to come of research resulting from the MIKIW.

Terry W. Moore
Editorial Advisory Board and Topic Editor (prior), ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters
University of Illinois Chicago

William C. K. Pomerantz
Topic Editor, ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters
University of Minnesota
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Celebrating the 60th Anniversary of the MIKIW Meeting-in-Miniature

virtual_issues.vi_title: Perspective, Review, and Featured Articles of 2023
virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Collection highlights the special articles written by invited authors and published in <cite>The Journal of Physical Chemistry C</cite> in 2023. These articles cover all sections of the journal: energy conversion and storage, catalysis and photocatalysis, and experimental and computational research on nanomaterials, low-dimensional materials, and bulk materials. One of the fastest growing areas of research in physical chemistry addresses the issues encountered in energy storage. Electrochemistry and electrocatalysis are also important areas of research and there is great interest in understanding chemical transformations at solid surfaces. In addition to uncovering the dynamics of processes, the physical chemistry research published in <cite>JPCC</cite> elucidates the structure and properties of materials through the development of instrumentation and the design of synthesis techniques. By collecting these articles together, we hope to provide the readers with a quick guide to current research in some of the hottest topics in physical chemistry research on solid state materials and interfacial phenomena.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A lattice structure

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Roland Lindh is a Professor at Uppsala University and chairman of the OpenMolcas project. His work has been integral to the development of new computational methods, making advances in both the evolution of theoretical ideas and their efficient implementation on computer hardware possible. After many years working on Molcas, Dr. Lindh has become the central driving and leading force of what has now become a community-wide open-source software project. Currently, he is also diving deeply into machine learning, investigating how it can be rigorously and efficiently exploited within the framework of multi-configurational methods. This special issue, made up of outstanding papers from Roland Lindh’s friends and colleagues, should serve as a confirmation of the friendship, inspiration, and scientific progress that has embodied his career thus far.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A magnifying glass, DNA, question bubble, a globe, a gear, and a lightbulb, books and hand.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This thematic issue delves into the latest research achievements spanning a wide spectrum of organic radicals, ranging from monoradicals to diradicals and multiradicals. Each paper in this virtual issue focuses on novel methods for synthesizing radicals, along with an in-depth analysis of their properties, particularly delving into the electronic states, offering a deeper understanding of electron transfer mechanisms and spin–spin interactions within or between molecules.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A collection of spheres with chemical diagrams of radicals inside them, against a backdrop of a spiral galaxy

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Malaria is a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Plasmodium parasites. This global health concern affects ~250 million people annually, resulting in over 600,000 death each year.

World Malaria Day is recognized on April 25th to raise awareness for this life-threatening disease. ACS Publications posted collections in 2022 and 2023 to highlight recent advances in diagnosing, treating, and combating malaria. In this 2024 Collection, you will find contributions from across 20 ACS journals. We hope our readers are inspired by the ongoing research efforts taking place across the globe.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: malaria

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Distinguished Professor Esther Sans Takeuchi, the William and Jane Knapp Chair in Energy and the Environment at Stony Brook University and Chief Scientist at Brookhaven National Laboratory, is an international leader in electrochemical energy storage systems (batteries). She invented the battery that enabled the implantable cardiac defibrillator, technology which has saved millions of human lives worldwide. Recognizing that access to clean, reliable affordable energy directly scales with quality of human life, her current research focus is new frontier electrochemical energy storage systems that can enable a clean energy future, ranging from applications in electrified transportation to electric grid level storage to demanding specialty requirements. The articles in this Festschrift, from friends, colleagues, current and former mentees, honor Esther Takeuchi’s ongoing research achievements and her leadership in the field of electrochemistry and electrochemical energy storage.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A globe, a certificate, a filled envelope, a timer, a book in front a globe, and an envelope

virtual_issues.vi_title: Spectroscopy, Structure and Reactivity of Stabilized Criegee Intermediates
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Unsaturated volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as isoprene and pinenes are emitted into the Earth’s lower atmosphere from various natural and anthropogenic sources. The ozonolysis reaction of an unsaturated VOC leads to a reactive intermediate carbonyl oxide, which can collide with N<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>2</sub> in air to become a stabilized Criegee intermediates (sCI). Laboratory and computational studies of the structures, spectroscopy, unimolecular isomerization and photodissociation pathways, and bimolecular chemical reactions of these sCIs are the subject of this Collection. Trends apparent in these publications include extension of the experimental and computational investigations to larger, structurally more complex sCIs than formaldehyde oxide and acetaldehyde oxide, and study of Criegee intermediate chemistry occurring in water and at the air-water interface. All these contributions are significantly advancing our understanding of the production and fates of sCIs in the Earth’s troposphere, whether by chemical reaction, uptake at water interfaces, or solar photolysis.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Subsection of a reaction pathway

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This virtual special issue feature articles on fundamental research and advances in technologies dependent on designing materials and engineering systems, and their future prospects prefaced with an Editorial by Linda J. Broadbelt (Northwestern University, United States, Associate Editor, ACS Engineering Au), Paul J. Dauenhauer (University of Minnesota, United States), Steven G. Arturo (The Dow Chemical Co., United States), and Ananth Govind Rajan (Indian Institute of Science - Bengaluru, India).
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Designing materials and engineering systems

virtual_issues.long_blurb: From plant growth to heating, Earth is powered by sunlight. The most prominent example is photosynthesis: Solar photons are absorbed by plants, which store their energy in the form of chemical bonds. Plants then use this stored solar energy to grow, creating food as well as feedstocks that can themselves be used as energy sources (e.g., wood, coal, petrol, and general fossil fuels). It is the intensive use of fossil fuels (accumulated solar energy saved over thousands of years) that is leading to a rocketing increase of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere and to global warming. A rapid and decisive transition towards clean and sustainable energy sources is urgently needed to revert this trend. Photonic sciences, dealing with the manipulation of photons – the most fundamental energy carrier – have already played a crucial role in such energy transition; and are increasingly doing so. This is the focus of this virtual special issue.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: photonics for energy

virtual_issues.long_blurb: <cite>I&ECR</cite> is proud to dedicate a special issue to honour Prof. Muthanna H. Al-Dahhan’s career marked by groundbreaking research, academic leadership, and dedication to training future generations of engineers. In this Virtual Special Issue, <cite>I&ECR</cite> gathered contributions from a global group of researchers in areas that are aligned with Dr. Al-Dahhan’s research.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Prof. Al-Dahhan in his lab. (Photo courtesy Prof. Al-Dahhan)

virtual_issues.vi_title: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning in Atmospheric Chemistry
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) methods are emerging as powerful tools in atmospheric chemistry research. From making use of petabytes of existing data, to improving accuracy on predictions of chemical constituent distributions, to processing and interpreting data in observational science and leveraging spatial relationships in air quality, such tools can offer insights that were once inconceivable.

This collection of recently published papers from across the ES&T family of journals shines a spotlight on recent developments in the use of AI and ML techniques to advance modern understanding of atmospheric chemical processes. There are many gaps in our current exploitation of these tools in this field, and their application may lead to inappropriate conclusions as their use evolves. But with a shared ethical responsibility and transparency in how they are applied, they have the potential to transform this field of research.

We hope you enjoy this curated collection of papers showcasing this area of rapid development in atmospheric chemistry.

Sam J. Silva and Mat Evans.

Chemical engineers and researchers are working together to tackle the climate crisis by creating sustainable energy solutions and developing energy sources that can help reduce the greenhouse gas emissions. This virtual special issue highlights cutting-edge research that addresses issues of sustainable energy production and storage, as well as decarbonization prefaced with an Editorial by Vivek Ranade (University of Limerick, Ireland, Deputy Editor, ACS Engineering Au), Rajnish Kumar (Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, India), and Matteo Maestri (Politecnico di Milano, Italy).
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Tackling the issues of sustainable energy generation and storage, along with decarbonization.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: The past decade has witnessed great progress made in the field of phase engineering of nanomaterials. We not only recognize the presence and importance of new phases or heterophases but also attempt to predict, design, fine-control, and transform new phases or heterophases with theoretical guidance, advanced characterization tools, and well-developed synthetic methodologies to gain more insights into phase–property–application correlations. This virtual thematic issue aims to bring timely snapshots of recent advances achieved in phase engineering of nanomaterials in selected subtopics, covering recent progress in theoretical and experimental efforts in syntheses, characterizations, property investigations, and applications of a variety of phase-engineered nanomaterials.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: thematic issue cover

virtual_issues.vi_title: Applications of Free-Energy Calculations to Biomolecular Processes
virtual_issues.long_blurb: The calculation of accurate free energies lies at the core of investigating biomolecular processes such as protein-ligand binding, protein-antibody interactions, enzymatic reactions, and solvation by means of computer simulations. Given their prevalence in cellular machinery, many of these processes have significant implications not only in various aspects of biophysics but also in the rational design of drugs. Consequently, it is highly desirable to predict their feasibility using theoretical tools. In recent decades, substantial strides have been made in determining free energies through the application of numerical simulations grounded in the fundamental principles of statistical mechanics. While the accessibility of computational resources, in particular the rapid development of fast and affordable graphics processing units, has contributed to these advancements, the primary catalyst for progress lies in the development of a diverse array of methods. These methods have effectively enhanced the efficiency and reliability of calculations related to free energy, opening new perspectives for the computational study of a variety of complex problems hitherto intractable. For this Collection, we have assembled 22 papers recently published in <cite>Journal of Chemical Information and Modeling</cite> and <cite>The Journal of Physical Chemistry B</cite> that serve as excellent examples of insight gained from free energy calculations.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Rendering from the crystal structure of a druglike inhibitor bound to a protein

virtual_issues.vi_title: Plastics, Human Health, and the Environment
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
In recognition of Earth Day 2024 which this year is themed ‘Planet vs. Plastics’, ES&T Letters presents a curated collection of recently published ES&T Letters articles investigating the human and environmental impacts of the ubiquitous presence of plastics in the environment.

This Collection highlights the latest research advances in understanding how nanoplastic and microplastic fragments present risks to human health and the environment. The papers included have investigated how human exposure is occurring via ingestion, inhalation, and medicinal routes. Articles include how ingestion of nano- and microplastic fragments in drinking water may affect fetal growth and development in humans (Aghaei et al., 2022), how the impact of exposure to environmentally relevant doses of microplastics may affect male reproductivity in terrestrial mammals with transgenerational effects on their offspring (Deng et al., 2022), how the environmental weathering of plastics may alter the adsorption behavior of nanoplastics in the blood stream to plasma proteins (Wen et al., 2022), the human inhalation exposure to microplastics via human inhaled indoor aerosol (HIA) and human exhaled breath (HEB) (Geng et al, 2023), the assessment of potential links between gestational exposure to selected plasticizers and antioxidants and placental functions in a population-based study (Jing et al., 2023), examining the dietary exposure of small infants to the complex cocktail of plastic additives present in baby food packaging (Tan et al., 2023), and assessing the exposure potential for microplastics to directly enter the bloodstream of humans via infusion therapy from the infusion-material containers (e.g., glass infusion bottles, plastic infusion bottles, plastic infusion bags, plastic infusion tubes) (Zhu et al., 2023).

The exposure of aquatic and terrestrial species to nano- and microplastics in the environment and potential adverse impacts is also included in this collection. Investigations include understanding the tissue-specific bioaccumulation of nano- and microplastics in the gills and ovaries of medaka Oryzias melastigma using stable carbon isotopes (Yeo et al., 2023), the responses of aquatic plants following exposure to microplastics in sediments and adverse impacts on the ecological assembly processes of the rhizosphere microbial community (Lin et al., 2023), and the assessment of nano- and microplastics in soil and impacts on plant functions (Azeem et al., 2022).

Additional papers in this collection examine potential solutions to reduce environmental plastic contamination and resulting exposure pathways. Schwartz-Narbonne et al. (2022) observe that significant levels of microplastics concentrate in wastewater treatment plants from human excretion pathways, despite sophisticated treatment procedures. Plastic fragments are deposited into settled solids, which are frequently used to enrich soils, affecting soil communities, plant health, and increased environmental dispersal via hydrologic and aeolian processes. The authors call for an upgrading of wastewater treatment approaches to tertiary level and the exclusion of floating or primary settled solids from land-applied biosolids. Wang et al. (2022) call for greater transparency in the chemicals used for plastics production to lessen the complexity in the environmental burden and consequently reduce risk to public health and ecosystems.

We hope you enjoy this curated collection of papers showcasing the latest developments in understanding exposure pathways and health impact assessments of nano- and microplastics in the environment, for the protection of our health and our environment.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: plastic debris in water

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Krishnan Raghavachari, Distinguished Professor of Chemistry at Indiana University, Bloomington, has had a broad impact on computational physical chemistry for over four decades. His work has spanned atomic clusters, semiconductor surface chemistry, and, more recently, larger-scale systems including protein-ligand interactions. Prof. Raghavachari’s development of computational methods underpins the many CCSD(T) and Gaussian-n calculations that are ongoing, somewhere in the world, almost constantly. In addition, he actively encourages his students and postdocs to nourish their personal relationships and to live well-rounded lives. This balanced approach of work and family has not only earned him the respect and friendship of all that have passed through his lab, but also ultimately resulted in a substantial body of impressive work from all his associates. These sixty-seven articles from friends, colleagues, and former mentees in this Festschrift honor Krishnan Raghavachari’s many contributions to physical chemistry as both a researcher and a mentor.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A tribute to Krishnan Raghavachari Festschrift

virtual_issues.vi_title: Advancing Materials for Environmental Remediation and Human Health Protection
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
This Collection presents reviews and research articles published in ACS ES&T Engineering that highlight intriguing scientific directions and technological concepts in environmental materials research. These five review articles and nine research articles reflect the richness and excitement of environmental materials research performed around the world.

The topics presented include electrified membranes, nanocomposite polymeric membranes, polyacrylonitrile/polyvinylidene-fluoride membranes for water treatment, novel adsorbents for air purification and phosphate removal, new formulations of TiO2 for thermo-, photo-, and electrocatalytic uses, bismuth phosphate-based materials for UVC-driven photocatalytic treatment of PFAS in water, graphitic carbon nitride for contaminant sensing and for dual-purpose catalysis, electrocatalytic reduction of nitrate using bimetallics or metal oxides and metal sulfides in place of platinum group metal elements, and piezoelectric materials to promote contaminant degradation in water.

We hope you enjoy this curated collection of papers showcasing the cutting-edge developments in materials research for the protection of our health and our environment.

Michael S. Wong, Jessica Ray and Steven L. Suib

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Membrane proteins make up over half of current drug targets, making them an especially important subject for both academic and pharmaceutical research. Because these proteins are inherently insoluble in aqueous solvents and require the presence of lipids or detergents to remain soluble, their analysis by mass spectrometry is challenging. However, over the past 10 to 15 years, substantial progress has been made in overcoming these hurdles. This Collection features articles published in <cite>Journal of the American Society for Mass Spectrometry</cite> and <cite>Analytical Chemistry</cite> that showcase recent advances in analyzing membrane proteins using a broad range of mass spectrometry-based approaches.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: proteins

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
The ALPACA project - Alaskan Layered Pollution And Chemical Analysis project - has been studying the significant air pollution in Fairbanks, Alaska and how cold and dark wintertime conditions affect this pollution. The project carried out a major intensive field experiment in January/February 2022 and has involved multiple scientists from the United States and Europe collecting air samples and data on the air quality of Fairbanks impacted by wood combustion for household heating, coal and oil power plant emissions, transportation and light industry. A key project focus is air pollution sources and chemistry in the cold and the dark, alongside the winter 'inversions' experienced in Fairbanks where cold, polluted air becomes trapped below layers of warmer air due to its geographic position surrounded by hills. Another key focus is indoor air quality where infiltration of air from very cold outdoor conditions to warmer indoor conditions changes particle and gas partitioning. We also study indoor sources of pollution.

ACS ES&T Air is showcasing ALPACA research papers in this rolling collection of published works on the topic in the journal. We hope you enjoy this curated collection of research coming out of this exciting and fundamental research study.

Prof. William Simpson for the ALPACA team

virtual_issues.vi_title: Hot Articles from the ACS Organic/Inorganic Journal Portfolio: 2023 Editors' Choice
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Organic and inorganic chemistry are the fundamental sources of inspiration for creativity across all areas of basic and applied chemistry, from crucial medicines to incredible materials. The world is ever improving thanks to the ingenuity of organic and inorganic chemists.

Keeping up with the pace of new research in these fields is a challenge. ACS Editors' Choice helps by filtering important new findings and making them free to read for six months so anyone, anywhere, can quickly apply them to their research.

This new collection of 54 Editors' Choice articles selected in 2023 from across the American Chemical Society's core organic and inorganic journals showcases innovative thinking and smart problem-solving in the areas of synthetic methodology, coordination and main-group chemistry, catalysis, solid-state inorganic and functional organic materials, natural products, energy research, biological and medical science, green chemistry, theoretical and computational chemistry, process chemistry, and more.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Hot electrons—electrons with energies far exceeding the thermal distribution—are generated in metallic nanostructures by light excitation or by non-thermal dynamics such as atomic and molecular scattering. Despite their short lifetimes, hot electrons (or holes) can induce chemical dynamics and catalytic processes. The study of electronic excitations at metal-organic interfaces provides a fertile ground for advancing the fundamental understanding and ultrafast control of light–matter interactions and the use of these interactions for selective catalysis and surface reaction dynamics. This VSI highlights exciting research on hot-electron phenomena across ultrafast spectroscopy, catalysis, and surface physics. The collection features 28 contributions and presents a rich mix of perspectives and aspects of hot-electron effects in catalysis.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: As explained on https://darwinday.org/, "The mission of International Darwin Day is to inspire people throughout the globe to reflect and act on the principles of intellectual bravery, perpetual curiosity, scientific thinking, and hunger for truth as embodied in Charles Darwin." Darwin’s own curiosity and scientific thinking played a pivotal role in establishing evolutionary biology. This theory provides a framework to explore topics such as the origins of unusual forms and functions, how bacteria gain resistance to antibiotics, and how changing environmental conditions can lead to new enzyme functions. We can also use our understanding of evolutionary variability and pressure to create new molecules through techniques such as ancestral reconstruction and directed evolution. This Collection captures new insights, advances, and techniques related to evolution; we hope they inspire you!

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Biological systems are capable of partitioning their components to retain nutrients, enable unique chemistry, protect delicate structures, and much more. It has been known for decades that the lipid membrane provides distinct and dynamic local environments for its constituents, yet new insights continue to expand our understanding of this complex milieu. More recent discoveries have established phase separation as a vehicle for proteins and other macromolecules to control catalysis, respond to environmental conditions, and more, with new advances continuing to challenge our fundamental understanding of biomolecular structure and function. This Collection captures the latest advances in both areas, as well as recent special issues and open calls for papers on related topics.

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Hiro-o Hamaguchi has left an indelible mark on the scientific community through his research in the field of molecular spectroscopy, in particular Raman spectroscopy, and his mentorship of numerous scientists from younger generations. Early in his career, he became a leader in time-resolved vibrational spectroscopy, with successes in measuring transient Raman spectra of prototypical short-lived transient species. Subsequent projects included advances in picosecond time-resolved Raman spectroscopy, femtosecond time-resolved UV-visible, near- and mid-infrared absorption spectroscopy, picosecond time-resolved fluorescence spectroscopy, coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering (CARS) spectroscopy, infrared electroabsorption spectroscopy, and hyper-Raman spectroscopy. He adeptly applied these techniques to study various photochemical phenomena such as photoisomerization, excited-state proton transfer, and charge transfer processes. One of the highlights was finding intermolecular vibronic coupling induced by solvent vibration, which was beautifully demonstrated through resonance hyper-Raman spectroscopy of beta-carotene. Expanding into new research areas, he began studies of ionic liquids and living cells. In the latter area, he used confocal Raman microscopy to track the cell division process in fission yeast and showed the importance of label-free live cell imaging at a very early time. In addition, he broadened the horizons of cancer diagnostics using near-infrared-excited Raman spectroscopy on surgical samples and minimizing autofluorescence in the resulting spectra. The 87 papers by Prof. Hamaguchi's friends and colleagues collected for this issue celebrate the remarkable legacy of his life's work.

virtual_issues.vi_title: <cite>Inorganic Chemistry</cite> 2023 Featured Articles: Unique, Inspiring, and Exceptionally Well-Done Chemistry

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Electromagnetic interference (EMI) is a phenomenon that occurs when an external source disrupts the normal functioning of an electrical circuit by generating unwanted electromagnetic fields from electromagnetic induction, electrostatic coupling, or conduction. It has become a new type of pollution, although invisible, in our modern society. To effectively reduce EMI in space or better, completely block electromagnetic fields, the development of EMI-shielding materials with high absorption capacity is critical. In this collection curated by our associate editor Dr. Dongling Ma, we showcase some of the high-quality original research papers or reviews published in <cite>ACS Applied Nano Materials</cite> on this trending topic.

Marsha I. Lester, the Christopher H. Browne Distinguished Professor of Chemistry at the University of Pennsylvania, has been a trailblazer in physical chemistry for over four decades. Her research has probed the dynamics of chemical reactions and the properties of weakly bound complexes. In particular, her extensive spectroscopy and photochemistry studies on Criegee intermediates and the hydroxyl and hydroperoxyalkyl radicals have dramatically impacted the scientific community’s understanding of these transient species and have resulted in far-reaching implications for atmospheric and combustion chemistry. Importantly, Prof. Lester has served as a mentor to numerous graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, instilling in them her unwavering practicality and meticulous preparation as well as her keen eye for good science and her contagious enthusiasm for research. The fifty articles from friends, colleagues, and former mentees in this Festschrift honor Marsha Lester’s ongoing research achievements and her legacy of mentorship and advocacy for women in physical chemistry.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Marsha I. Lester Festschrift VSI cover art

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Chemistry of Materials celebrated its 35th anniversary in 2023, and this Collection of papers showcases an excellent selection of the most cited and downloaded content, as well as papers that attracted wider media attention and some recommended reading from our editorial team that was published during this significant milestone in the journal’s history.

We hope you enjoy exploring the Collection and we encourage you to read the accompanying Editorial written by Editor-in-Chief Professor Sara Skrabalak.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: virtual issue cover image

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Throughout his career, Professor Zhao-Wu Tian closely monitored international scientific developments and was among the first to recognize that the kinetics of electrode processes represented the forefront of modern electrochemistry. Not only did he possess a comprehensive understanding of traditional electrochemical theory and methods, he also consistently infused modern technological advancements and elements into the field, making him one of the founding figures and catalysts for expanding modern electrochemistry in China. He successfully developed 15 distinctive electrochemical instruments, including an instrument that encompasses all transient and steady-state electrochemical techniques and pioneering research methods, earning it the nickname of the "Pride of Chinese Electrochemistry." It broke the country’s long-standing dependence on imported electrochemical instruments, significantly advancing the progress of electrochemical methods in China. In order to address urgent issues in China, such as environmental protection, petroleum conservation, alleviating traffic congestion, and the transformation of the automotive industry, Zhao-Wu Tian, near a hundred years of age, continues to contribute actively, working diligently to share his scientific insights.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Zhao-Wu Tian Festschrift Collection cover art

virtual_issues.long_blurb: Synthetic biology is enabling scientists to tackle important societal problems, but is held back by our inability to predict biological systems as accurately as we predict and simulate physical or chemical ones. Artificial Intelligence and machine learning can improve this predictive power, and can be applied in all parts of the synthetic biology process. This Virtual Special Issue highlights topics benefiting from artificial intelligence and machine learning, along with state-of-the-art architectures already being explored in the domain.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: A brain made out of electrical circuits

virtual_issues.vi_title: Women Scientists at the Forefront of Energy Research (Part 6)
virtual_issues.long_blurb: As part of our annual celebration of the contributions of female scientists, we bring you part six of this Collection series. From early career researchers to well-established senior scientists, the successful career paths they have taken to become leaders in the community have impacted energy research in a significant way. The contributions of female energy researchers who have published new advances from their laboratories in <cite>ACS Energy Letters</cite> are compiled along with their short inspirational stories. To inspire other scientists working in the field, we asked them to comment on their inspiration to engage in energy research, discuss an "aha!" moment in research, and/or provide advice to newcomers in the field. We hope that these personal reflections compiled in this Collection can motivate many young researchers to tackle challenges in clean energy.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: Women Scientists at the Forefront of Energy Research collection cover art

virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Collection captures recent innovations within the field of molecular diagnostics that use CRISPR enzymes to advance technologies for nucleic acid detection, improving our measurement capabilities and inspiring the next generation of point-of-care diagnostics.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: An artistic rendering of DNA

virtual_issues.vi_title: Rising Stars in Proteomics and Metabolomics 2024
virtual_issues.long_blurb: In this Collection, we recognize emerging scientists in the fields of proteomics and metabolomics selected by the Associate Editors of the <cite>Journal of Proteome Research</cite> (<cite>JPR</cite>) and the Editorial Advisory Board members. The 34 authors included in this Collection are all early career researchers (from graduate students to newly appointed Associate Professors and Research Scientists), have a publication in one of the ACS measurement science journals, and have already demonstrated incredible originality and promise for the future of proteomics and metabolomics. Please take a look at the list below and read through the papers included in this Collection. We wish them all great success and thank them for sharing their journey with <cite>JPR</cite>.
virtual_issues.thumbnail_alt_text: rising stars

virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Selective chemical or biocatalytic functionalization of an already structurally complex molecular scaffold has emerged as a powerful means of generating interesting new structures. Probably most familiar in the current era, scaffold diversification for purposes of improving properties relevant in medicinal chemistry has become almost de rigueur in the pharmaceutical and biotech industries. Different strategies encompassing both classical and contemporary approaches have enabled access to new structures of value.

The more recent, diverse inventions of synthetic methodology as a field unto itself, and also the advent of catalytic chemistries and new reagents, made the time right for explosive growth in late-stage functionalization. Stereo-, regio-, chemo- and site-selectivity challenges all accumulate when considering derivatization of structurally and functionally complex molecular core structures. The result has been powerful and exciting literature under the banners of scaffold diversification, remodeling, editing, and, of course, late-stage functionalization itself. Presented in this virtual thematic issue is a completely fresh set of manuscripts that deal with the different facets of late-stage functionalization.

virtual_issues.vi_title: Interface Science Advances in Latin America
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
Latin America comprises South and Central America, the Caribbean islands, as well as Mexico in North America. The relevance of this Virtual Issue extends beyond borders, underlining the global significance of Latin American contributions in several areas of interfacial chemistry that cover the multidisciplinary scope of Langmuir, such as nanomedicine, nanoparticles, hydrogels, interfaces and films, biomimetic membranes, and theory and simulation. We aspire, that this Virtual Issue servers as a source of inspiration in further investigations, fostering cross-cultural scientific collaborations and providing deeper appreciation of the pivotal role of Latin American researchers in advancing the fields published in Langmuir.

Karin A. Riske, Guest Editor
Department of Biophysics, Federal University of São Paulo, Brazil

virtual_issues.vi_title: Highlights from our Editorial Advisory Board
Drug Resistance in Infectious Diseases and Beyond
virtual_issues.long_blurb:
This Virtual Special Issue features articles, reviews and viewpoints, covering themes such as: finding a comprehensive action plan on antimicrobial resistance; drug resistance across bacterial, fungal, parasitic and viral pathogens; therapeutic approaches using small molecules and natural products, antibody-based therapy, and CRISPR-mediated therapy; vaccines for infectious diseases; and host-responses to pathogens. We hope this collection inspires collaboration and innovation, driving our shared mission to address this critical global health crisis.

Jayanta Haldar, Editor-in-Chief
Courtney C. Aldrich, Past Editor-in-Chief
Celia A. Schiffer, Guest Editor
Daria J. Hazuda, Guest Editor

virtual_issues.vi_title: Celebrating 60 Years of The Chinese University of Hong Kong: Research Highlights in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology
Physical Chemistry of Quantum Information Science
virtual_issues.long_blurb: This Virtual Special Issue was inspired by recent innovations and discoveries in the active research field of quantum information science (QIS).  Control of molecular quantum states has improved dramatically thanks to advances in producing cold molecular beams and trapped gas samples. Manipulation of individual molecules in optical tweezers and of many-body interactions in various optical lattice configurations have opened exciting possibilities. Likewise, control of quantum states has been achieved or proposed in a variety of materials, from defects in bulk materials to thin films and quantum dots and even large molecules such as dyes and fullerenes. The breadth of quantum technologies to which these molecular and materials platforms have the potential to cater is vast, including areas of sensing, computing, quantum optics, and beyond. In this VSI, we explore quantum information science where molecular systems take center stage.

Research and Development of Novel Secondary Batteries in Japan
virtual_issues.long_blurb: Rechargeable batteries are essential for establishing a sustainable, carbon-neutral society based on renewable energies. CO<sub>2</sub> emissions from transport, which account for around 20% of total CO<sub>2</sub> emissions, can be reduced by increasing the number of electric vehicles operated by rechargeable batteries, and the large-scale introduction of renewable energy, which fluctuates with time, requires rechargeable batteries to stabilize the energy supply. Lithium-ion batteries are most widely used for these applications, but their energy and power densities need to be improved, and their cost is too high. Thus, the development of innovative next-generation rechargeable batteries is required. The Japan Science and Technology Agency (JST) and the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) started the first large-scale project on next-generation batteries, the Advanced Low Carbon Research Program (ALCA) - Specially Promoted Research for Innovative Next Generation Batteries (SPRING) in 2013. It was designed to promote research in a top-down approach by teams to realize practical batteries, including all-solid-state, lithium-sulfur, lithium-air, and magnesium batteries. The hope is that this VSI will accelerate the research and development of innovative next-generation batteries worldwide through international collaborations.
